name: United States
notes_C1: As of April 5, at least 12 states require in-person instruction to be available in all or some grades either full- or part-time. This includes Iowa, West Virginia, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Florida, Texas, New Mexico, and Arkansas to fully open K-12, with partial reopenings required by Washington, Oregon, Arizona, and Massachusetts. All other states continue to operate with a mix of remote, hybrid, and in-person learning across grade levels.     The CDC released update guidelines for testing and screening of higher education colleges and universities in mid-March.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210414224128/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-where-are-schools-closed/2020/07     https://web.archive.org/web/20210414231521/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/colleges-universities/ihe-testing.html
notes_C2: CDC guidance continues to urge protection measures such as mask wearing, physical distancing, and reduced capacity within businesses to limit the spread of Covid-19. At the state level, many states continue to use re-opening frameworks based on Covid-19 prevalence (and some have lifted capacity limits completely). For example, in Colorado counties fall into one of six color-coded levels of risk. Under level green, the least restrictive, most businesses can operate without restrictions. Indoor bars and indoor entertainment venues must limit capacity to 50 percent or 500 people, whichever is smaller. In level-blue counties, restaurants and gyms can operate at 100 percent capacity as long as parties maintain a 6-foot distance from one another. Indoor bars can operate at 25 percent capacity, with a maximum of 75 patrons. Retail stores can operate at 75 percent capacity.    On March 31, 2021, Governor Holcomb of Indiana signed Executive Order 20-9, extending the statewide mask mandate until April 6 and a county-by-county approach to restrictions. After that, the health department will offer a mask advisory and guidance on gatherings, but it will be up to local authorities and businesses to implement restrictions. Under current restrictions, counties designated as red or orange (areas with the highest risk of coronavirus spread) must limit social gatherings to 25 percent of a facility’s capacity. Counties designated as yellow must limit gatherings to 50 percent of a facility’s capacity. Counties designated as blue can operate at full capacity, as long as social distancing, mask wearing and other precautions are followed.     Louisiana Governor John Bel Edwards is lifting some restrictions on businesses as of March 31 through Proclamation number 66 JBE 2021. The majority of businesses, including restaurants, bars, gyms and hair salons, no longer have capacity limits. Businesses must continue to keep waiting areas closed, and restaurants still cannot allow self-serve buffets. Indoor gatherings and event centers are capped at 50 percent capacity or 500 people (whichever is less).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210412202119/https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial-dashboard    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412202518/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/communication/guidance-list.html?Sort=Date%3A%3Adesc&Audience=General+Public+%3E+Employers%2C+Business+Owners+%26+Community+Leaders    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412202908/https://www.in.gov/gov/files/Executive-Order-21-09-Modification-of-County-Based-Restrictions.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412203114/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412203306/https://gov.louisiana.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/3058    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412203733/https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/66-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-COVID.pdf
notes_C3: Many states continue to ease COVID-19 restrictions on public gatherings and are gradually allowing many public event venues to open with a specified percentage of original capacity. For example, Governor Carney of Delaware modified restrictions on outdoor gatherings. Effective April 1, outdoor events at venues without a fire-occupancy limit are capped at 150 people. If a venue of 100,000 square feet or more has an outdoor occupancy limit, it must restrict capacity to 50 percent. If an outdoor venue of 100,000 square feet or under has an outdoor occupancy limit, it must restrict capacity to 75 percent. With permission from the health department, outdoor gatherings of more than 150 people are allowed. Public indoor events continue to be limited to 50 percent of the venue’s fire occupancy or 25 people (whichever is smaller). With permission from the health department, public indoor gatherings of up to 150 people are allowed.    In Maine, outdoor gatherings at a venue with occupancy limits can operate at 75 percent capacity until May 24, when they can increase to 100 percent capacity.     In Mississippi, events at indoor arenas are permitted to operate at 75 percent seating capacity. K-12 organized events, such as sports competitions, are limited to 50 percent capacity.    In Rhode Island, venues of assembly, such as concert halls and spectator-sport facilities, can operate indoors at 50 percent capacity, with a cap of 250 people (if outdoors, the cap is 500). Social gatherings of up to 15 people are permitted indoors and of up to 50 people if held outside.    Link to Delaware press release: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412204338/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/03/29/governor-carney-signs-eighth-revision-to-omnibus-covid-19-order/    Link to Mississippi: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412205539/https://www.wlox.com/2021/03/31/gov-tate-reeves-extends-executive-order-limiting-capacity-indoor-arenas-public-events/    Link to AARP state-by-state COVID-19 policies:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412203114/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
notes_C4: As of 12 April, states are beginning to revise their restrictions on gatherings based on vaccination status. For example, in Vermont "If you are fully vaccinated: You may gather with other fully vaccinated people or households. You don’t need to wear a mask or stay 6 feet apart when you gather.  You may gather with up to two unvaccinated people or households at a time. The gathering can also include other vaccinated people or households."    Several states continue to have restrictions on gatherings of 10 or fewer people. For example: Ohio (10 or fewer people), Oregon (Extreme and High Risk: Limit the gathering to no more than six people, indoor. Moderate Risk: Limit the gathering to no more than eight people, indoor. Lower Risk: Limit the gathering to no more than 10 people, indoor), Kentucky, Indoor social gatherings are recommended to have no more than eight people from a maximum of two households, and in Washington all counties are in Phase 3 of the state's reopening plan, which has a limit of 10 people for social gatherings.    Vermont: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412211848/https://apps.health.vermont.gov/COVID/faq/  Ohio: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412212358/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/amended-directors-order-for-social-distancing-21.pdf  Oregon: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412212934/https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2351g.pdf  Washington: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412213659/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C5: The CDC's Order that requires face masks to be worn by all travelers while on public transportation (which includes all passengers and all personnel operating conveyances) continues to be in effect. "People must wear masks that completely cover both the mouth and nose while awaiting, boarding, disembarking, or traveling on airplanes, ships, ferries, trains, subways, buses, taxis, and ride-shares as they are traveling into, within, or out of the United States and U.S. territories. People must also wear masks while at transportation hubs (e.g., airports, bus or ferry terminals, train and subway stations, seaports, U.S. ports of entry, and other locations where people board public transportation in the United States and U.S. territories)."    There are no known complete closures of public transit systems above the local level.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210412214744/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/face-masks-public-transportation.html
notes_C6: On March 31, 2021, Georgia extended the Public Health State of Emergency to April 30, 2021. This order enacts Shelter at Home restrictions for those at risk for severe illness.     South Dakota Governor Noem signed an order putting the state’s “Back to Normal” plan in effect, which encourages, but doesn’t require, older adults and other vulnerable individuals to stay at home.    AARP state-by-state policy changes: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412215512/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412215604/https://covid.sd.gov/docs/COVID_SDPlan_BackToNormal.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404191556/https://gov.georgia.gov/executive-action/executive-orders/2021-executive-orders
notes_C7: On April 2 the CDC updated its guidance on travel restrictions within the US. "Fully vaccinated travelers are less likely to get and spread COVID-19.  People who are fully vaccinated with an FDA-authorized vaccine can travel safely within the United States: Fully vaccinated travelers do not need to get tested before or after travel unless their destination requires it. Fully vaccinated travelers do not need to self-quarantine. Fully vaccinated travelers should still follow CDC’s recommendations for traveling safely including: Wear a mask over your nose and mouth, stay 6 feet from others and avoid crowds, wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer."     The CDC provides links to health departments in all 50 states, 8 US territories and freely associated states, and the District of Columbia for reference to subnational-level restrictions on internal movement. Some states continue to have quarantine and/or testing requirements for travelers. For example, people coming to Hawaii should be prepared to undergo a 10-day quarantine upon arrival and closely monitor their health OR undergo pre-testing from a trusted partner in the SafeTravels Pre-testing Travel program.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210414003827/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210414003921/https://www.cdc.gov/publichealthgateway/healthdirectories/healthdepartments.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210414004501/https://hawaiicovid19.com/travel/
notes_C8: According to the CDC travel website, "Several Presidential proclamations established restrictions on the entry of certain travelers into the United States in an effort to help slow the spread of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)." The list includes the suspension or limited entry from: China, Iran, European Schengen area (Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Monaco, San Marino, Vatican City) United Kingdom (England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland), Republic of Ireland, Brazil, and South Africa.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412221740/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 11, President Biden signed the American Rescue Plan into law. The $1.9 trillion pandemic relief bill includes direct cash payments of $1,400, $300 federal boost to weekly jobless benefits, an expansion of the child tax credit of up to $3,600 per child and $350 billion in state and local aid.     Link to Plan text: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414214206/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319/text
notes_E2: The 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.     Part of the American Rescue Plan (which became law on March 11) includes appropriations to the Secretary of the Treasury for the Homeowner Assistance Fund established under subsection (c) for fiscal year 2021, "out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $9,961,000,000, to remain available until September 30, 2025, for qualified expenses." Qualified expenses, as outline in the Plan, include: "purpose of preventing homeowner mortgage delinquencies, defaults, foreclosures, loss of utilities or home energy services, and displacements of homeowners experiencing financial hardship after January 21, 2020, through qualified expenses related to mortgages and housing, which include—    (A) mortgage payment assistance;  (B) financial assistance to allow a homeowner to reinstate a mortgage or to pay other housing related costs related to a period of forbearance, delinquency, or default;  (C) principal reductions  (D) facilitating interest rate reductions;  (E) payment assistance for—  (i) utilities, including electric, gas, home energy, and water;  (ii) internet service, including broadband internet access service, as defined in section 8.1(b) of title 47, Code of Federal Regulations (or any successor regulation);  (iii) homeowner’s insurance, flood insurance, and mortgage insurance; and  (iv) homeowner’s association, condominium association fees, or common charges;  (F) reimbursement of funds expended by a State, local government, or designated entity under subsection (f) during the period beginning on January 21, 2020, and ending on the date that the first funds are disbursed by the eligible entity under the Homeowner Assistance Fund, for the purpose of providing housing or utility payment assistance to homeowners or otherwise providing funds to prevent foreclosure or post-foreclosure eviction of a homeowner or prevent mortgage delinquency or loss of housing or utilities as a response to the coronavirus disease (COVID) pandemic; and  (G) any other assistance to promote housing stability for homeowners, including preventing mortgage delinquency, default, foreclosure, post-foreclosure eviction of a homeowner, or the loss of utility or home energy services, as determined by the Secretary    The Plan also includes emergency rental assistance (Subtitle B).       Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414213132/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to American Rescue Plan text: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414214206/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319/text
notes_H1: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) continues its coordinated public information campaign. The US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) also launched the HHS COVID-19 Public Education Campaign, a national initiative to increase public confidence in and uptake of COVID-19 vaccines while reinforcing basic prevention measures such as mask wearing and social distancing.     "Through a nationwide network of trusted messengers and consistent, fact-based public health messaging, the campaign helps the public make informed decisions about their health and COVID-19, including steps to protect themselves and their communities. The effort is driven by communication science, and provides resources, toolkits, advertising, and tailored information for at-risk groups."    CDC COVID-19 website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414215427/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/index.html    HHS: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414215720/https://www.hhs.gov/coronavirus/education-campaign/index.html
notes_H2: According to the CDC website, "anyone with any signs or symptoms of COVID-19 get tested, regardless of vaccination status or prior infection." All states have testing locations that are free and do not require insurance or payment.     The American Rescue Plan dedicated funds towards expanding testing, including the implementation of "a national, evidence-based strategy for testing, contact tracing, surveillance, and mitigation with respect to SARS–CoV–2 and COVID–19" and "establish and expand Federal, State, local, and territorial testing and contact tracing capabilities." (Subtitle E- Testing).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210414220102/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/testing.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210414214206/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319/text
notes_H3: Contact tracing is conducted on a statewide level, and is often further decentralized by county or local health departments or contracted out to private organizations. Not all states report their contact tracing statistics, so it is difficult to gauge the efficacy of contact tracing.     According to the CDC Covid-19 data dashboard, 8.25% of tests were positive over the past 7 days (as of April 14). As an example of contact tracing efforts, for the week of April 4, Oregon's contact tracers reached 84% of Covid-19 cases identified within a 24 hour period. Their goal is to reach 95% of cases. During the same timeframe, only 36.2% of positive cases were traced to a known source, and their goal is to trace at least 70% of cases to a known source.     Funds from the American Rescue Plan (signed into law March 11) are meant to provide technical assistance to states, municipalities, territories, and tribes to help trace and monitor the spread of Covid-19.     CDC: https://archive.vn/yvN69    Link to Plan text: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414214206/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319/text    Link to Oregon data: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414221835/https://public.tableau.com/profile/oregon.health.authority.covid.19
notes_H6: The US continues to have a patchwork of mask mandates, with more states increasingly rolling back requirements and deferring to local/county governments to issue their own requirements. According to AARP, twenty-seven state governments currently require people to wear face coverings in public to curb the spread of COVID-19. The District of Columbia and Puerto Rico also have mask orders in place.    Kansas Governor Kelly signed an order on April 1 that extended a mask mandate, but the Legislative Coordinating Council voted to rescind it. A law that went into effect last month requires the council to review any executive order related to the pandemic and gives them the authority to revoke it.     Michigan Governor Whitmer and the state health department updated coronavirus-related restrictions, effective through April 19, including face mask requirements remaining in place for those age 5 and older as the state sees a surge in positive cases.     New Hampshire Governor Sununu extended a mask mandate through April 16. The order requires individuals over age 5 to wear face coverings in indoor or outdoor public spaces if social distancing with people from other households cannot be maintained.     Kansas: https://archive.vn/nRpNi  Michigan: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414223035/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-553387--,00.html  New Hampshire: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414223449/https://boston.cbslocal.com/2021/03/25/new-hampshire-mask-mandate-extended-21-days-chris-sununu/    AARP state-by-state: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414223559/https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html
notes_H7: On April 13 the CDC and FDA released a joint statement on the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) vaccine, which is reported to have caused blood clots in six  individuals who received the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine. The statement says that as of April 12, more than 6.8 million doses of the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen ) vaccine have been administered in the U.S.     "CDC will convene a meeting of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) on Wednesday to further review these cases and assess their potential significance. FDA will review that analysis as it also investigates these cases. Until that process is complete, we are recommending a pause in the use of this vaccine out of an abundance of caution. This is important, in part, to ensure that the health care provider community is aware of the potential for these adverse events and can plan for proper recognition and management due to the unique treatment required with this type of blood clot."    Given this news, it is likely that states will pause the use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine and will continue to use Pfizer and Moderna vaccines; this may delay timelines for vaccine eligibility to wider groups of people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210414011900/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/s0413-JJ-vaccine.html

name: Alaska
notes_C1: The largest university in Alaska, University of Alaska Anchorage, continues through the spring semester to hold courses primarily via alternate course delivery, remote work and controlled access to campus facilities. A mandatory mask policy is in effect at all UAA campuses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407191815/https://www.uaa.alaska.edu/
notes_C2: Anchorage's Emergency Order 19 remains in effect as of April 7. All restaurants, bars, breweries, and night clubs can open at reduced capacity to maintain physical distancing. Indoor entertainment facilities, indoor gyms and fitness centers can also operated with reduced capacity (masks required). Establishments offering sit-down service of any kind must have visitor logs in order to assist with contact tracing. Employers must require employees to work from home if remote work is feasible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C3: Anchorage's EO-19  "Make it a Safe Spring" plan limits gathering sizes. Outdoor gatherings were consumption of food and drink occurs is limited to 60 people, without food and drink, 100 people. Indoor gatherings are limited to 25-35 people. Entertainment facilities are allowed to operated at reduced capacity with masking and physical distancing, along with other health precautions.     Health Advisory No. 1 remains in effect statewide, which recommends avoiding all gatherings outside of your household.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C4: Health Advisory No. 1 remains in place statewide, recommending Alaskans to "Avoid all gatherings, even small ones, with persons who are not in your household." (health advisories are not "mandated").    Anchorage's Executive Order 19, limits outdoor gatherings were consumption of food and drink occurs is now limited to 60 people, without food and drink, 100 people. Indoor gatherings are limited to 25-35 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C5: The People Mover in Anchorage continues to operate with safety measures in place, " People Mover and AnchorRIDES continue to operate regular service and rider limits remain at 14-riders per 40-foot bus and 6-riders per vehicle on the neighborhood routes with 22-foot buses. Cloth face coverings are still required to ride People Mover."     https://archive.vn/II4oD
notes_C6: Anchorage's EO-19 encourages people to avoid contact with those outside their household and to limit trips outside the home.    Health Advisory No. 1 also remains in effect statewide ("Minimize time indoors with individuals outside your household even if you can maintain a distance of six feet. Avoid all gatherings, even small ones, with persons who are not in your household.")     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C7: Health Advisory No. 3 remains in effect (first issued Feb 14), which provides guidance on intrastate travel, including recommending testing, physical distancing, and quarantining as necessary both on and off the Road System and Alaska Marine Highway System. "Anyone who is currently infected with SARS-CoV-2 virus must not travel until they are cleared from isolation by a medical professional."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410204530/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-3-Intrastate-Travel.pdf
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: Unemployment assistance is available. The Division of Public Assistance lists other resources available to Alaskans on their website.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211043/https://labor.alaska.gov/COVID-19-programs.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_E2: There are no active statewide moratoriums or suspensions of utility shutoffs. The CDC eviction moratorium is in effect. Those who qualified for the rental assistance program (applications closed March 5) will have access to 12 months of rental assistance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410213801/https://www.muni.org/Departments/Mayor/PressReleases/Pages/Municipality-of-Anchorage,-Cook-Inlet-Housing-Authority-partner-with-Alaska-Housing-to-distribute-up-to-12-months-of-rent-a.aspx
notes_H1: The public continues to be informed about Covid-19, vaccination and testing, etc. As an example:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410215810/https://public.govdelivery.com/assets/Signup.js
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is widely available to the public.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210410220041/https://coronavirus-response-alaska-dhss.hub.arcgis.com/app/2d92b77bc8044329a1ee3954b063bd8c
notes_H3: Alaska has a contact tracing program, though it is not clear how thorough it is.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322232305/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_H6: Anchorage's Executive Order 13 v4 remains in effect, face coverings are required in all public spaces. Alaskans are generally encouraged to follow CDC guidance and wear masks under Health Advisory 1, which was issued February 14 and remains in effect until rescinded.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194051/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo13v4.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf
notes_H7: The COVID-19 vaccine is available for anyone living or working in Alaska who is age 16 or older. According to a press release on April 2, Alaska’s vaccination effort continues to be one of the most expansive in the US. Nearly one-in-three Alaskans (253,240 people) have received their first shot while more than one-in-five (177,827 people) are fully vaccinated.    Vaccination coverage is highest among Alaska residents age 65 and older, roughly 72% of Alaskans in that age group have received one dose of the vaccine and 64% are fully vaccinated – a number that includes 90% of residents at Alaska’s Pioneer Homes (as of April 2).     The available vaccines are Moderna, Pfizer, and Johnson & Johnson.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407195521/https://gov.alaska.gov/newsroom/2021/04/02/alaska-continues-to-lead-nation-in-vaccination-rates/

name: Alabama
notes_C1: On 5 April, Alabama's last holdout district, Montgomery County Public Schools, returned to in-person learning for those students who wished to do so. This signalled a change in the code from 2T (require closing some levels) to 1G (significant differences in in-person school operations across the state). Because the state-wide "Safer at Home" order requires schools to maintain social distancing, disinfect surfaces, and require face coverings, 1G is the appropriate code instead of 1T or 0.    Read Montgomery County's in-person school announcement on their Facebook page: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405202244/https://www.facebook.com/MontgomeryPublicSchools/photos/a.212460712110982/4312853038738375/
notes_C2: As Governor Kay Ivey's revised "Safer at Home" order remains in place until 9 April, there are no changes to business recommendations.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329210946/https://covid19.alabama.gov/
notes_C3: As Governor Kay Ivey's revised "Safer at Home" order remains in place until 9 April, there are no changes to gathering recommendations.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329210946/https://covid19.alabama.gov/
notes_C4: As Governor Kay Ivey's revised "Safer at Home" order remains in place until 9 April, there are no changes to gathering recommendations.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329210946/https://covid19.alabama.gov/
notes_C5: There is no longer any evidence, as of 22 March, that Birmingham is reducing its routes for COVID-19. Now, their website only mentions increased sanitation procedures.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322214945/https://maxtransit.org/
notes_C6: As Governor Kay Ivey's revised "Safer at Home" order remains in place until 9 April, there are no changes to the recommendation to stay home if unwell.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329210946/https://covid19.alabama.gov/
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On 3 March, Alabama announced it would be participating in a new mixed earner unemployment compensation program. Under this program, claimants will receive up to $100 per week in supplemental benefits if they can prove they were self-employed in 2019 and receiving at least $5,000 in net income for that tax year. This scheme is only for informal workers. Separate programs target formal workers, thus the code's flag has been expanded to all workers.    Read more here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210309115313/https://labor.alabama.gov/news_feed/News_Page.aspx?id=331
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: Alabama Department of Public Health continues its coordinated COVID-19 media campaign, across traditional and new media platforms, such as Facebook.     See their Facebook page here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329212852/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Falabamapublichealth
notes_H2: On February 1, The Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) will offer COVID-19 testing in Coffee and Houston counties during the month of February. Due to limited staffing in this district and COVID-19 vaccination clinics, testing is only being provided on alternate weeks in Coffee and Houston counties at this time. No COVID-19 retesting will be done.  Testing clinics are scheduled as follows:  Coffee County Health Department  2841 Neal Metcalf Road  Enterprise, AL 36330  (334) 792-9070  Tuesday, February 2, and Tuesday, February 16  8:30 a.m. until 10:30 a.m.    Houston County Health Department  1781 E Cottonwood Road  Dothan, AL 36301  (334) 792-9070  Wednesday, February 10, and Wednesday, February 24  8:30 a.m. until 10:30 a.m.  Symptoms of COVID-19 consist of either cough or shortness of breath (difficulty breathing) or at least two of the following: fever, chills, repeated shaking with chills, muscle pain, headache, vomiting, diarrhea, sore throat, fatigue, congestion or runny nose, and new loss of taste or smell.  Testing criteria are as follows:  Persons with symptoms  Healthcare facility workers, workers in congregate living settings, and first responders with symptoms  Persons without symptoms who have underlying medical conditions or disability placing them at a higher risk of complications or screening of other asymptomatic individuals based on a case-by-case review and approval by the state health department or local health jurisdiction.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210205195826/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/news/2021/02/01.html
notes_H3: On 25 February, the Alabama Department of Public Health launched an online survey to learn more about COVID-19 spread and response to contact tracing. "Any Alabama resident who has ever tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 . . . is asked to complete the survey." There is no indication that contact tracing is comprehensive in the state, however.     Read more here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210309123414/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/news/2021/02/25.html
notes_H6: Governor Kay Ivey's revised "Safer at Home" order remains in effect until 9 April. No changes to the mask policy.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329210946/https://covid19.alabama.gov/
notes_H7: On 3 April, Governor Kay Ivey announced that beginning Monday, 5 April, anyone aged 16 and older is eligible for the vaccine in Alabama. Alabama is currently giving Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson formulations. Alabama State Health Officer Scott Harris noted that, "The increased supply of safe and effective vaccines means all adults who wish to be vaccinated are now eligible to receive the protection vaccines offer." Based on the nature of vaccine appointments in the state (with some facilities offering walk-up jabs if there is excess supply), we can assume jabs are going into arms beginning 5 April.    Read the press release about her statement here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203220/https://governor.alabama.gov/newsroom/2021/04/governor-ivey-announces-covid-19-vaccination-eligibility-to-be-expanded-in-alabama-to-include-individuals-age-16-and-older/

name: Arizona
notes_C1: As per State of Arizona Executive Order 2021-04, on March 15th all schools in the state returned to 100% in-person classes if their levels of COVID-19 transmission within the schools are below the Moderate Transmission Threshold. Schools are required to keep track of COVID-19 cases and respond appropriately with respect to the outlined 4-tier transmission chart. Schools that are eligible for 100% in-person classes must also enforce mask wearing and 6ft social distancing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403203301/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-04.pdf
notes_C2: On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that rescinded all county and city orders that enforced mask mandates, with the exception of mask mandates applied to government buildings and public transportation. Previous restrictions on businesses, such as gyms and indoor theatres, have been replaced by recommendations/suggestions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331090712/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405222129/https://azdhs.gov/documents/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/novel-coronavirus/community/indoor-theaters.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405222144/https://azdhs.gov/documents/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/novel-coronavirus/community/indoor-gyms-fitness-centers.pdf
notes_C3: On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that events larger than 50 people no longer require local government approval. The city of Phoenix, however, requires applications for gatherings exceeding 50 people to be filed and approved before events can occur. All events require the use of masks and social distancing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406174020/https://www.phoenix.gov/citymanager/specialevent    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331090712/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf
notes_C4: On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that events larger than 50 people no longer require local government approval. The city of Phoenix, however, requires applications for gatherings exceeding 50 people to be filed and approved before events can occur. All events require the use of masks and social distancing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406174020/https://www.phoenix.gov/citymanager/specialevent    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331090712/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf
notes_C5: There are no measures on closing public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210324213610/https://www.azdhs.gov/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/index.php
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html

Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently." notes_H3: The State of Arizona is running a comprehensive contact tracing system that involves contacting people who tested positive for COVID-19 via phone call, monitoring symptoms with a text/email system, and contacting all of the people that the case has made close contact with while infectious.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406202209/https://www.azdhs.gov/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/index.php
notes_H6: As of April 6th, the city of Phoenix asserted its rights to maintain their city-wide mask mandate passed in a city council declaration on June 20, 2020. This comes after the governor of Arizona released an executive order on March 25th that rescinded all county and city orders that enforced mask mandates, with the exception of mask mandates applied to government buildings and public transportation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210328163624/https://www.phoenix.gov/newsroom/em-and-hs/1353  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405194611/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf  Note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: Additional link to news report covering continued mask mandates in Pheonix, Flagstaff and Tucson in defiance of the executive order -  https://archive.fo/zJ6zZ
notes_H7: As of April 5th, all Arizona counties have made the vaccine available to all people ages 16+. Pfizer, Moderna, and Janssen vaccines are being distributed across the state.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411060904/https://www.azdhs.gov/documents/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/novel-coronavirus/vaccine-phases.pdf

name: California
notes_C1: The University of California system continues its remote-only instruction with the exception of a limited number of in-person or hybrid courses through the spring term. The California State University system will remain remote until Fall 2021 as well.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210323140526/https://covid-19.ucla.edu/plans-for-spring-quarter-remote-instruction-and-work/    https://archive.fo/H3HWk
notes_C2: As of April 5,  2 counties are in the Widespread tier, where many non-essential indoor businesses are closed (including: indoor movie theaters, gyms and fitness centers, bars, amusement parks, offices).  22 counties are in the Substantial tier, some non-essential indoor businesses are closed, 32 counties are in the Moderate tier, and 2 are in the Minimal tier.    Map of counties and tier assignments: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407025145/https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/     Blueprint with Tier info: https://archive.ph/sQrPz
notes_C3: As of April 5, 2 counties were in the highest restriction tier. In the highest tier level - Widespread, only outdoor gatherings are allowed with a maximum of three households. In all lower level tiers, indoor gatherings are allowed (also maximum of three households) but are strongly discouraged.     Map of counties and tier assignments: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407025145/https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/   Blueprint with Tier info: https://archive.ph/sQrPz
notes_C4: As of April 5, 2 counties were in the highest restriction tier. In the highest tier level - Widespread, only outdoor gatherings are allowed with a maximum of three households. In all lower level tiers, indoor gatherings are allowed (also maximum of three households) but are strongly discouraged. Though no numerical value is assigned to the restriction, the 11-100 level is appropriate as most households can be assumed to be 10 individuals or less.     Map of counties and tier assignments: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407025145/https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/  Blueprint with Tier info: https://archive.ph/sQrPz
notes_C5: The governor of California designated as essential: "Mass Transit and Passenger Rail includes terminals, operational systems, and supporting infrastructure for passenger services by transit buses, trolleybuses, monorail, heavy rail—also known as subways or metros—light rail, passenger rail, and vanpool/rideshare"     This designation remains in place and was last updated March 25.      Essential workers list: https://archive.fo/Hv8hF
notes_C6: On March 22, the Mayor of Los Angeles issued the following order, which remains in place:    "Under the provisions of Section 231(i) of the Los Angeles City Charter and Chapter 3,  Section 8.27 of the Los Angeles Administrative Code, I hereby declare that the Targeted  Safer at Home Order, dated December 2, 2020 and subsequently revised on December  31, 2020, is withdrawn and superseded by this Order, which is necessary for the  protection of life and property in the City of Los Angeles and is effective immediately:  1. Subject only to the exceptions outlined in this Order, all persons living within the  City of Los Angeles are hereby ordered to remain in their homes..."    (This appears to be the same order referred on March 16, though perhaps re-issued)    The full order can be read here: https://archive.fo/eI3m8
notes_C7: Gov. Newsom has lifted the earlier guidance that residents limit travel to 120 miles from their place of residence. The new guidance reads: "All travelers should follow the CDPH Travel Advisory. It asks that you:        Postpone non-essential travel until you are fully vaccinated      Follow CDC travel guidance      Isolate and follow public health recommendations if you test positive or develop symptoms of COVID-19.    If you are unvaccinated:        Avoid non-essential travel      If you must travel, get tested 1-3 days before travel, and 3-5 days after travel      After travel, self-quarantine for 7 days, no matter what your test results were. If you didn’t get tested, self-quarantine for 10 days."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410163515/https://covid19.ca.gov/travel/
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: Recent legislation issued by the Governor remains in place, which creates uniform, statewide policy to ensure employees have access to COVID-19 supplemental paid sick leave through September 30, 2021.    https://archive.fo/hmiA2
notes_E2: Utilities continue to not be disconnected due to non-payment. The California Public Utilities Commission extended utility customer protection measures directing energy, water, and communications companies under CPUC jurisdiction to suspend customer disconnections for non-payments from April 16, 2021 to June 30, 2021.    The EO extending the statewide moratorium on evictions continues to be in place, lasting through June 30, 2021.     PUC: https://web.archive.org/web/20210316001410/https://docs.cpuc.ca.gov/PublishedDocs/Published/G000/M365/K316/365316626.PDF    EO on rent moratorium: https://web.archive.org/web/20210323154518/https://www.gov.ca.gov/2021/01/29/governor-newsom-signs-legislation-to-extend-eviction-moratorium-and-assist-tenants-and-small-property-owners-impacted-by-covid-19/
notes_H1: California maintains an official COVID-19 website, which includes links to local county COVID-19 information as well as a video campaign to encourage vaccinations.     https://archive.fo/fnGUb
notes_H2: "Free, confidential COVID-19 testing is available to every Californian that needs it"    https://archive.fo/fnGUb
notes_H3: Contact tracing is being conducted in California, but it is unclear how extensive or thorough these measures are.     https://archive.fo/gRyMR
notes_H6: "Every Californian must wear a mask or face covering in all public and workplace settings where there is a high risk of exposure. This is more important than ever with new, more easily transmitted variants of COVID-19 on the rise."    https://archive.fo/U59lV
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson    As of today, "individuals aged 50+ are eligible to make an appointment, and individuals 16+ will be eligible to make an appointment to be vaccinated starting on April 15."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410192835/https://www.gov.ca.gov/2021/03/25/state-expands-vaccine-eligibility-to-50-californians-starting-april-1-and-all-individuals-16-on-april-15-based-on-expected-supply-increases/

name: Colorado
notes_C1: On Tuesday, January 5th many school districts resumed classes. A number of school districts in the Denver area, including Denver Public Schools, are resuming classes remotely.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210105014704/https://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/thousands-of-colorado-students-return-to-in-person-learning-tuesday
notes_C2: Counties with strictest regulations are in Level Orange: offices are strongly recommended to work remotely, restaurants at 25% capacity or max 50 people, retail at 50% capacity.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C3: Per the Department of Public Health and Environment of Colorado, events are recommended to be canceled unless appropriate social distancing measures can be taken.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C4: Counties with strictest regulations are in Level Orange: gatherings restricted to up to 10 people.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C5: RTD's COVID-19 service plan continues - mask-wearing requirements, limited capacity on buses, services/lines running reduced.     Link: https://archive.fo/84v6F
notes_C6: Counties with strictest regulations are in Level Orange: people advised to stay at home as much as possible.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: The Governor extended an Executive Order ordering expedited unemployment insurance claim processing to provide relief to Coloradans impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.   Link: https://archive.fo/IHZ7V
notes_E2: Governor Polis extended an Executive Order providing relief to public utility customers affected by COVID-19. Link: https://archive.fo/G3CWg    Governor Polis also extended an Executive Order related to protections provided to Colorado tenants from late fees due to COVID-19. Link: https://archive.vn/Tzy4A
notes_H1: Governor Polis announced the launch of a COVID awareness campaign by the Colorado Tourism Office. The “Do Colorado Right” campaign aims to encourage both in-state and out-of-state winter travelers to avoid risky behaviors during the pandemic as they visit the State’s ski resorts and other destinations for the current winter and upcoming spring seasons.    Link: https://archive.vn/LNtjX
notes_H2: As of right now, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment wants to remind Coloradans that there are numerous state-sponsored community testing sites across the state. They are free, convenient, and do not require a doctor’s note, identification, or insurance. There are more than 50 free community testing sites across the state, as well as dozens of locations offered by private providers.     COVID19 testing sites are generally available to everyone even people who do not experience any symptoms.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210310120954/https://covid19.colorado.gov/press-release/free-and-convenient-testing-sites-available-across-colorado
notes_H3: Couldn't find more recent news, but sources in mid-late November indicate that contact tracing capacity wasn't keeping up with the number of surging cases at the time.  Links: https://archive.fo/00vsj ; https://archive.fo/wH1g5    More recent (Jan 10) anecdote/Twitter thread suggesting limited contact tracing: https://archive.fo/dkEVT
notes_H6: As of March 26th, A mandatory mask-wearing requirement for Colorado went into effect in July 2020 and recently was amended in Executive Order D 2021 056 on March 5, 2021 until April 3, 2021. It may continue to be extended if necessary.    The Executive Order allows the state to grant limited waivers for people to go without masks for a limited time to perform specific, one-time indoor activities that cannot otherwise be performed while wearing a mask, provided the activity can be done safely. Exemptions will not be granted to requests where it would be easier or more comfortable to perform the activity without the mask.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210326044125/https://covid19.colorado.gov/mask-guidance
notes_H7: On March 19th, Colorado expands its COVID-19 phase to 1B.4, which expands 2.5 million people. Vaccination Phase 1B.4 includes people 50 and older and frontline workers in several fields, including food service, education, manufacturing, public transit, journalism and people serving in various government roles. Those 16 to 49 years old with one eligible high-risk condition will also be eligible, as well as adults who received a placebo in a COVID-19 vaccine trial.    Moderna, Pfizer, and Johnson & Johnson will be available and are being administered.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210327012838/https://www.9news.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/vaccine/covid-vaccine-eligibility-colorado-expands/73-2e0328a4-8213-45f7-bed3-1b3749cfa4d1

notes_C1: "The state is moving ahead full throttle to get all students back inside classrooms come the fall, but the efforts will most likely fall short, Gov. notes_C5: No change
notes_C6: On 5 November, the Connecticut State Health Department issued a statewide advisory advising all residents to stay home from 10PM to 5AM. Coded as targeted since the recommendation only covers night hours.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322010334/https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/11-2020/Governor-Lamont-Coronavirus-Update-November-5    On February 1, curfew on restaurants and other businesses extended to 11pm   https://web.archive.org/web/20210404200012/https://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/coronavirus/watch-live-at-4pm-governor-lamont-provides-update-on-states-coronavirus-response-vaccine-distribution/2411519/
notes_C7: No change:   "Beginning March 19, 2021, Connecticut’s travel advisory will be modified from a requirement to recommended guidance. You will no longer be required to fill out a CT Travel Health Form to travel, and we will not be providing Travel Complaint Forms."    "As of March 19, 2021, Governor Lamont’s Executive Order No.9S, Section 1 regarding travel is no longer in effect.    Connecticut residents and travelers to Connecticut should follow travel-related guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Connecticut Department of Public Health (CT DPH). Mandates and requirements are not currently in place in Connecticut."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322034843/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Travel    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035359/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Travel
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: No change.    From the executive order 9P:  "NOW, THEREFORE, I, NED LAMONT, Governor of the State of Connecticut, by virtue of the  authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the State of Connecticut, and pursuant  to the public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on March 10, 2020 and renewed on September 1, 2020 and the new public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on September 1, 2020, do hereby ORDER AND DIRECT:    1. Increase in Weekly Benefit Amount and Qualification for Lost Wages Assistance. Notwithstanding any provision of Chapter 567 of the Connecticut General Statutes to the contrary, during the weeks beginning July 26, 2020, and ending on September 5, 2020, individuals who were eligible for a Weekly Benefit Amount of less than $100.00 and had not exhausted their state regular unemployment benefits by July 26, 2020, shall have their Weekly Benefit Amount raised to $100.00, and such individuals shall be permitted to apply for Lost Wages Assistance as a result. With respect to employers who make payments in lieu of contributions pursuant to Section 31-225 of the Connecticut General Statutes (reimbursing employers), for individuals who are affected by this Executive Order No. 9P, the amount otherwise due from the employer in lieu of contributions shall be reduced by an amount equal to the difference between the individual’s Weekly Benefit Amount to be paid pursuant to this Order and the Weekly Benefit Amount which was or would have been calculated pursuant to Chapter 567 prior to this Order. The Commissioner of Labor may issue any implementing orders that he deems necessary to effectuate this order.    This order shall take effect immediately and remain in effect for the duration of the existing  renewed and newly declared civil preparedness and public health emergencies, unless earlier  modified or terminated by me."    From executive order 10:  "Exclusion of individual stimulus payments from benefit eligibility calculations: Repeats and expands the provisions of Executive Order No. 7CC, which exempted any CARES Act stimulus payments from eligibility calculations for state-provided benefits. This expands the exemption to all federal COVID-related stimulus to capture CARES Act II stimulus."    Sources:  https://archive.vn/gkjem    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192050/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9P.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192106/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-10.pdf
notes_E2: No change  "Governor Ned Lamont, members of Connecticut’s Congressional delegation, and Connecticut Housing Commissioner Seila Mosquera-Bruno today announced the launch of UniteCT, a new state program to provide rental and utility assistance to qualified Connecticut households financially impacted by COVID-19.    As further detailed in the program guidelines, UniteCT may provide up to $10,000 in rental assistance and up to $1,500 in electric utility arrearage payments to landlords and utility companies on behalf of approved tenants. Tenants and landlords will be able to complete and track applications online from any computer or smart phone. Assistance will be available through a call center and at housing counseling agencies and other community partners across the state."    Source:  https://archive.vn/WbftJ
notes_H1: No change. Campaigns appear up to date.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319095243/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base
notes_H2: No change.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322041525/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/COVID-19-Testing
notes_H3: No change.    "Contact tracing is the process of contacting all people who have tested positive for COVID-19 or have had contact with someone who tested positive. It is possible to be infected with COVID-19 and have no symptoms, so contact tracing is currently one of the best ways to identify and notify people who may be infected in order to slow the spread of COVID-19. Participating in contact tracing is a way to protect you, your family, and your community.    Contact tracers from the local and state health department will be in touch with you if you test positive for COVID-19, and will also call people you were in close contact with – but will keep your information protected. You will see “CT COVID TRACE” or the number for your local health department on your caller ID."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322043051/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/ContaCT
notes_H6: No change.    "Pursuant to Executive Order No. 7NNN, masks or cloth face coverings that cover a person's nose and mouth are required to be worn when in public and a six-foot distance is unavoidable, whether indoors or outdoors. This does not apply to anyone for whom doing so would be contrary to their health because of a medical condition. Guidance on face coverings has been issued to the state's businesses."    Source:  https://archive.vn/tuSTJ
notes_H7: Students, employees, and residents 16 and older now eligible for vaccine     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404194108/https://portal.ct.gov/vaccine-portal/COVID-19-Vaccination-Phases    "Those who are 16 and 17 years old can only register for the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. The vaccines developed by Moderna and Johnson & Johnson have only been approved for use on those 18 and older."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404194822/https://www.ctpost.com/news/coronavirus/article/Live-Connecticut-opens-vaccines-to-anyone-16-and-16068352.php
