name: Delaware
notes_C1: It has been difficult to determine remotely exactly which Delaware schools are open for in-person learning. However, a press release from the state government of 29th March 2021 indicates that Delaware households which have been affected by school closures, specifically the lack of school meals, during the pandemic will receive additional temporary food benefits up to July 2021. This implies that at least some schools were still closed as of that time, so this indicator remains at 2T until more clear information becomes apparent.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329212729/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/03/29/delaware-households-affected-by-school-closings-during-pandemic-will-receive-additional-temporary-food-benefits/
notes_C2: The latest modification to the State of Emergency Declaration, passed on 1st April 2021, does not stipulate restrictions on workplaces beyond safety measures that retail establishments must take (social distancing, requirement for customers to wear a face covering, etc). Therefore this indicator remains at 1G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210412130906/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/04/Ninth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-04012021.pdf
notes_C3: As of 12th April 2021, the latest modification to Delaware's State of Emergency Declaration has not changed the policy on public events. However, public indoor gatherings are still capped at 50% of the building's fire occupancy; therefore this indicator remains at 1G.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210412130906/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/04/Ninth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-04012021.pdf    http://web.archive.org/web/20210407010758/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_C4: As of 12th April 2021, there has been no further update to Delaware's restrictions on gatherings since the Eighth Revision to the State of Emergency Declaration, which increased the gathering limit to 150 people. Therefore this indicator remains at 2G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210403010916/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/03/Eighth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-03292021-1.pdf
notes_C5: DART's COVID-19 strategy outline, which was last updated on 21st March 2021, indicates that most public transport services are ?currently (as of 12th April 2021) running. Therefore this indicator remains at 0.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210325131129/https://dartfirststate.com/newsy/covid-19/COVID-19-Strategy-at-a-Glance.pdf?07092020
notes_C6: Delaware's latest guidance, which was updated on 1st April 2021, does not mention staying at home. Therefore this indicator remains at 0.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210407010758/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_C7: The Twenty-Seventh Modification to Delaware's Declaration of the State of Emergency, which recommends that students participating in out-of-state tournaments immediately self-quarantine, and that state employees “refrain from any business travel out of state unless the Department Head (or authorized agent) deems such travel essential”, is still in effect as of 12th April 2021. Therefore this indicator remains at 1G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210407010758/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: A press release from the state government of 29th March 2021 indicates that Delaware households which have been affected by school closures, specifically the lack of school meals, during the pandemic will receive additional temporary food benefits up to July 2021. As these benefits are temporary and specifically related to the pandemic, and as they amount to only $6.82 per eligible child per day, this indicator remains at 1F.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329212729/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/03/29/delaware-households-affected-by-school-closings-during-pandemic-will-receive-additional-temporary-food-benefits/
notes_E2: As of 12th April 2021, the Delaware Housing Assistance Program is still in effect. Given this, and the continuing moratorium on utility shut-offs, this indicator remains at 2.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210412152329/https://decovidhousinghelp.com/
notes_H1: The Delaware official state Twitter account is still providing information on COVID-19; see tweet below on vaccination do's and don'ts.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409120212/https://twitter.com/delaware_gov/status/1380491030949199876
notes_H2: On 2nd April 2021, Governor Carney announced the seven community COVID-19 testing sites operating during the week beginning 5th April 2021.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405190157/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/04/02/governor-carney-dph-dema-announce-community-covid-19-testing-sites-24/
notes_H3: As of April 2021, 127,037 people have been identified by Delaware's contact tracing system.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409021049/https://myhealthycommunity.dhss.delaware.gov/about/acceptable-use
notes_H6: The latest update to Delaware's State of Emergency Declaration specified that athletes participating in outdoor high-risk sports (contact sports) must wear face coverings at all times. Those participating in low-risk sports must wear face coverings at all times when not engaged in play on the field, and all coaches, staff, and referees must wear them at all times. Those engaged in indoor sports must also wear them at all times.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210401171458/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/04/01/governor-carney-updates-covid-19-order/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210407011036/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/04/Ninth-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-04012021.pdf
notes_H7: On 6th April 2021, Delaware opened its vaccination programme to everybody over the age of 16. As this is a recent development and it is as yet unclear (as of 12th April 2021) whether the state's capabilities can live up to this promise, this indicator moves to 4I rather than 5.     As of Monday, April 5, Delaware had administered 502,927 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine. Nearly 35 percent of Delaware’s population had received at least one shot.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210406145309/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/04/06/covid-19-vaccination-program-open-to-delawareans-16/

name: Florida
notes_C1: Florida Department of Education Order No. 2020-E0-07, signed on the 30th November 2020, remains in force. The order states that “all schools remain open” and that “all school boards and charter school governing boards must continue to open brick and mortar schools at least five days per week for all students."    According to the Return to Learn tracker, it appears all schools in Florida are fully in-person with COVID-19 alterations.    Link to Florida Dept of Education Order No 2020-EO-07:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227173837/http://www.fldoe.org/core/fileparse.php/5673/urlt/DOEOrder2020-EO-07.pdf  Link to Return to Learn tracker:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412181151/https://www.returntolearntracker.net/
notes_C2: On a statewide level, Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect. Enacted 26 February 2021, Executive Order 21-45 extends the Florida state of emergency declared by Executive Order 20-52, 20-114, 20-166, 20-192, 20-213, 20-276, 20-316 for 60 days (until 26 April 2021). Executive Order 21-45 does not impose any workplace closings.    Code remains 2T to reflect the continuing restrictions on sidewalk cafe operations in restaurants in the City of Miami Beach.     Miami-Dade County:  On 05 April 2021, Miami-Dade County issued Emergency Order 33-20, which "states a minimum occupancy of 50 percent for restaurants and other food establishments, and that these establishments shall be allowed to operate at up to 100 percent if the establishment ensures 6 feet of distance between tables and ensures that persons not actively eating or drinking are wearing facial coverings."    The City of Miami Beach Declaration of a State of Emergency relating to a High Impact Period (Spring Break) was amended on 06 April 2021 and is in effect until 13 April 2021. The order continues to suspend all sidewalk cafe operations and outdoor restaurant seating each night from 8pm to 6am in the High Impact Zone.    Broward County:  According to the Broward County Comprehensive Emergency Order 20-30 (enacted 07 December 2020), food service establishments are allowed to operate with up to 100% of maximum indoor occupancy provided the establishment abides by certain social distancing and facial covering restrictions (Section 12.A, Page 22/63). Per the Broward County website, the order appears to be in continued effect, with the exception of Sections 12.B.1 and 12.B    Link to Executive Order 21-45: https://web.archive.org/web/20210314021257/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to list of Miami-Dade County Emergency Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330164938/http://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/emergency-orders.page  Link to Miami-Dade County Emergency Order 33-20:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210406114008/https://www.miamidade.gov/information/library/04.05.21-emergency-order-33-20.pdf  Link to Miami Beach State of Emergency Order, amended 06 April 2021:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406222639/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Declaration-of-a-State-of-Emergency-EO-2021-06-SB.pdf  Link to Broward County Emergency Orders:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329220337/https://www.broward.org/CoronaVirus/Pages/EmergencyOrders.aspx  Link to Broward County Comprehensive Emergency Order 20-30: https://web.archive.org/web/20210307194330/https://www.broward.org/CoronaVirus/Documents/Comprehensive-Emergency-Order-20-30.pdf
notes_C3: Miami-Dade County continues to enforce 50% capacity restrictions on meeting and entertainment venues since September 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403054020/https://www.miamigov.com/Government/Stand-Up-Miami/Reopening-City-Service-Updates/Entertainment-Meeting-Venues      Miami Beach extends Declaration of State of Emergency: "Commencing on Thursday, April 1, 2021, through the morning of Monday, April 5, 2021, from 8:00 p.m. through 6:00 a.m. each night, all sidewalk café operations, including expanded outdoor restaurant seating, shall be SUSPENDED in the High Impact Zone."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210403053401/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Declaration-of-State-of-Emergency-EO-2021-05-SB.docx.pdf
notes_C4: On March 25th, Miami-Dade County extended the state of emergency for seven days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326040440/https://www.miamidade.gov/information/library/03.24.21-state-of-emergency-declaration-extension-55.pdf     On March 31, Miami Beach extends emergency order another 7 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210403053401/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Declaration-of-State-of-Emergency-EO-2021-05-SB.docx.pdf
notes_C5: The only mandate for transit services mentioned is that all riders must wear a mask per the Miami-Dade County emergency order.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210403055602/https://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/transit-services-updates.page    On March 25th, Miami-Dade County extended the state of emergency for seven days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326040440/https://www.miamidade.gov/information/library/03.24.21-state-of-emergency-declaration-extension-55.pdf     On March 31, Miami Beach extends emergency order another 7 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210403053401/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Declaration-of-State-of-Emergency-EO-2021-05-SB.docx.pdf
notes_C6: On a statewide level, Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect. Enacted 26 February 2021, Executive Order 21-45 extends the Florida state of emergency declared by Executive Order 20-52, 20-114, 20-166, 20-192, 20-213, 20-276, 20-316 for 60 days (until 26 April 2021).     Executive Order 21-45 does not impose any curfews. Until 12 April 2021, Miami-Dade County and all municipalities continue to mandate a county-wide curfew from midnight to 6 a.m. every day. The curfew expiration date was set forth by Amendment No. 5 to Miami-Dade County Emergency Order 27-20. Municipalities may continue to impose more stringent standards within their jurisdiction.    The City of Miami Beach Declaration of a State of Emergency relating to a High Impact Period (Spring Break) was amended on 06 April 2021 and is in effect until 13 April 2021. The order cancels the curfew within the High Impact Zone that was imposed at the start of the High Impact Period.    There do not appear to be any curfews in Broward, Palm Beach, or Hillsborough counties. After today, if there are no new curfews, code should be downgraded accordingly.    Link to Executive Order 21-45:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210314021257/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Amendment No 5 to Miami-Dade Emergency Order 27-20:  https://archive.vn/MvA4j  Link to Miami Beach State of Emergency Order, amended 06 April 2021:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406222639/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Declaration-of-a-State-of-Emergency-EO-2021-06-SB.pdf
notes_C7: On a statewide level, Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect. Enacted 26 February 2021, Executive Order 21-45 extends the Florida state of emergency declared by Executive Order 20-52, 20-114, 20-166, 20-192, 20-213, 20-276, 20-316 for 60 days (until 26 April 2021).    There are no statewide restrictions on movement between cities and regions within Florida, but the City of Miami Beach continues to prohibit vehicular traffic on Ocean Drive.    The City of Miami Beach Declaration of a State of Emergency relating to a High Impact Period (Spring Break) was amended on 06 April 2021 and is in effect until 13 April 2021. The order continues to prohibit vehicular traffic on Ocean Drive and other public roads within the High Impact Zone at the discretion of the Interim City Manager or Chief of Police. Ocean Drive is open to pedestrians except during the general Miami-Dade curfew (midnight to 6am daily).    Link to Executive Order 21-45: https://web.archive.org/web/20210314021257/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to Miami Beach State of Emergency Order, amended 06 April 2021:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406222639/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Declaration-of-a-State-of-Emergency-EO-2021-06-SB.pdf
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: The Miami-Dade County website continues to provide information on how to "stop the spread" of Covid-19 and details regarding vaccines, testing, and county reopening.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330164934/http://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/home.page
notes_H2: FL has expanded testing sites, however, each site has different eligibility requirements (continued to select 2 to reflect potential requirements by individual sites).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403062034/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/testing-sites/
notes_H3: According to the FL Department of Health, "all Floridians [are urged to] answer calls from (833) 917-2880, (833) 443-5364 and (850) 583-2419 as this is part of Florida’s comprehensive contact tracing effort."    Although Florida has attempted contact tracing efforts, it remains unclear whether they've been effective. According to a news article on 31 March 2021, Governor DeSantis claims contact tracing did not work. Contact tracing was outsourced by the FL Department of Health to a company called MAXIMUS in May 2020, but the company has only released contact tracing data from July to August 2020. There was a decrease in calls made from July to August 2020.    Link to FL Department of Health FAQ page with contact tracing information: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406014238/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/frequently-asked-questions/  Link to news article on contact tracing (published 31 March 2021): https://web.archive.org/web/20210411151800/https://www.wtsp.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/florida-contact-tracing-coronavirus-a-mess/67-bff18da2-f797-4b01-8adf-9c03169fc4cf
notes_H6: Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect. Enacted 26 February 2021, Executive Order 21-45 extends the Florida state of emergency declared by Executive Order 20-52, 20-114, 20-166, 20-192, 20-213, 20-276, 20-316 for 60 days (until 26 April 2021).    There are no mask mandates at a statewide level; rather, mask wearing is enforced on a county and city level.     In Miami-Dade County, Emergency Order 33-20 (effective 06 April 2021) stipulates that "all persons throughout Miami-Dade County shall wear a mask or other facial covering when in public, except as set forth in Section 5C of the order." Exceptions include in private residences, while exercising, etc.    Code changed to 2T to reflect spectrum of exceptions to face coverings in the Miami-Dade order (masks are only required in some but not all public environments).     Link to Executive Order 21-45: https://web.archive.org/web/20210314021257/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to Miami-Dade County Emergency Order 33-20:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210406114008/https://www.miamidade.gov/information/library/04.05.21-emergency-order-33-20.pdf
notes_H7: As of 05 April 2021 per Executive Order 21-79 (enacted 29 March 2021), vaccination is open to all Floridians age 16+.    Available vaccines include: The Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for use in persons 16 years of age and older. The Moderna COVID-19 vaccine for use in persons 18 years of age and older. The Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) vaccine for use in persons 18 years and older. All COVID-19 vaccines are free to Floridians.     See Miscellaneous note on 02 April 2021 for information on vaccine passports.    Link to FL Department of Health FAQ page with vaccine information:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408072759/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/vaccine-eligibility/  Link to EO 21-79: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329220358/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-79.pdf

name: Georgia

"When DPH is notified of a case (a person with confirmed COVID-19), the case is interviewed and people they had close contact with (within 6 feet for 15 minutes or longer) beginning two (2) days before they became ill are identified.  DPH will then reach out to these individuals either by phone or text message to inform them that they have come in contact with someone with COVID-19  and enroll them in symptom monitoring. Individuals will be asked to monitor their symptoms and report any symptoms through a text messaging system, or by calling DPH if unable to text, and are asked to self-quarantine after their last contact with the case."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411224052/https://dph.georgia.gov/contact-tracing
notes_H6: No new updates since March 15, 2021 with Administrative Order for Long Term Care Facilities providing limits for visitors. name: Hawaii
notes_C1: The Hawaii DoE maintains a portal to track and share information re infection outbreaks in school facilities, and advises on a detailed action plan in the case of a positive case. This action plan includes targeted and temporary school closures, if required.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405133626/https://www.hawaiipublicschools.org/ConnectWithUs/MediaRoom/PressReleases/Pages/COVID-19-Information-Updates.aspx
notes_C2: "Order 2: All businesses with a facility in the City, except Essential Businesses, and Designated  Businesses and Operations, are required to cease all activities within such facilities, except  Minimum Basic Operations. For clarity, businesses may also continue operations consisting  exclusively of employees or contractors performing activities at their own residences (i.e.,  working from home). To the extent applicable and to the greatest extent feasible, Essential  Businesses, and Designated Businesses and Operations, shall comply with applicable Social  Distancing Requirements."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322182543/http://www.honolulu.gov/rep/site/may/may_docs/2103048-1_CCH_Amendment_to_COVID-19_Recovery_Framework_certified_-_signed.pdf
notes_C3: "31. Structured Events at Venues.  This section applies to structured events at venues (e.g., convention centers, banquet rooms, etc.) for industry and education purposes (“Structured Events”).  Structured Events may take place under the following conditions:   a. General conditions  i. Static events only.  Only static events are allowed at this time.  Static events are those in which attendees reserve a seat, attend the seated event, and leave.  Examples of static events include business/educational seminars, business meetings, and graduations.  b. Specific conditions  i. Capacity limits.  Occupancy must be limited to no more than the number that allows each attendee to maintain six (6) feet of physical distance from other attendees at all times....."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190920/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening
notes_C4: On March 23rd, the governor of Hawaii ordered:  "any gathering of more than ten  people is prohibited unless exempted by this Third Supplementary Proclamation.  Nothing herein prohibits the gathering of members of a household or residence."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210225093644/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/2003162-ATG_Third-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-signed.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210327083035/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/2004144-ATG_Sixth-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf
notes_C5: There are quarantine requirements placed on interisland travel, but no official guidance on suspension of available services.  "Order 4: Travel, including, but not limited to, travel on foot, bicycle, scooter, motorcycle,  automobile, or public transit, for Essential Travel and Essential Activities is permitted. This  Order also allows travel into or out of the City to perform Essential Activities, operate or visit  Essential Businesses, operate or visit Designated Businesses and Operations, or maintain  Essential Governmental Functions. All other travel is prohibited. Individuals should limit use of  public transit to the greatest extent possible (i.e., use only for purposes of performing Essential  Activities; or to travel to and from Essential Businesses or to maintain/access Essential  Governmental Functions). Individuals using public transit must comply with applicable Social  Distancing Requirements, including the face covering requirements contained in Order 5 below."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322184632/http://www.honolulu.gov/rep/site/may/may_docs/2102128-CCH_Emergency_Order_No._2021-02_Implementing_Tier_3_part_1_certified_-_signed.pdf
notes_C6: "All individuals currently living within the City may leave their residences to engage in  Essential Activities, maintain Essential Governmental Functions, operate/visit Essential  Businesses, or operate/visit/utilize Designated Businesses and Operations. All other activities,  businesses, and operations are prohibited. "  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322184632/http://www.honolulu.gov/rep/site/may/may_docs/2102128-CCH_Emergency_Order_No._2021-02_Implementing_Tier_3_part_1_certified_-_signed.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190920/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening
notes_C7: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322184632/http://www.honolulu.gov/rep/site/may/may_docs/2102128-CCH_Emergency_Order_No._2021-02_Implementing_Tier_3_part_1_certified_-_signed.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190920/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: On March 11th, the state of HI stated that they would be continuing unemployment benefits and rental/mortgage assistance due to the passing of federal legislation providing the state more money. notes_E2: On March 11th, the state of HI stated that they would be continuing unemployment benefits and rental/mortgage assistance due to the passing of federal legislation providing the state more money. notes_H3: On March 10th, the department of health of Hawaii outlined their results from a contact tracing effort, which appears to be comprehensive.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200830042219/https://health.hawaii.gov/news/covid-19/covid-19-daily-update-march-10-2020/
notes_H6: Masks are required in all public places.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210330024455/https://hawaiicovid19.com/mask-guidance/
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson    "HONOLULU – The Hawai‘i Department of Health announces the state will extend COVID-19 vaccine eligibility to people age 60 and older beginning Monday, March 29.    “We are closely monitoring current and projected vaccination numbers, appointment availability and most importantly the amount of vaccine allocated to the people of Hawai‘i,” said State Health Director Dr. Elizabeth Char.  “Our analysis of these indicators tells us it is time to expand vaccine eligibility to more people.”    To date vaccines have been reserved for those in phase 1a and 1b of the state’s vaccination program as well as those age 65 and older, those being treated with oxygen for severe respiratory conditions, those on dialysis, chemotherapy or other infusion therapy, as well as essential workers at hotels, restaurants, and bars."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404225511/https://health.hawaii.gov/news/newsroom/vaccinations-expand-to-people-age-60-and-older/

Twitter: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405173903/https://twitter.com/IAPublicHealth/status/1379126344664154116   Iowa's Covid-19 website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210411195735/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/
notes_H2: On March 15, two state-operated Test Iowa drive-thru sites will close early today due to heavy snow and ice expected in eastern Iowa.     The sites located in Waterloo and Cedar Rapids will open as usual at 8 a.m. today, but are scheduled to close early at noon.       Individuals whose appointments are cancelled due to the change in hours can bring their QR code to any site during regular hours to be tested. There is no need to take the assessment again or schedule a new appointment time.    Locations and hours of operation for all test sites can be found at testiowa.com or coronavirus.iowa.gov.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210316021410/https://governor.iowa.gov/press-release/test-iowa-sites-in-waterloo-cedar-rapids-to-close-early-due-to-weather-conditions
notes_H3: As of January 4th, there was no evidence that the state of Iowa had ramped up contact tracing. Thus, the coding stays the same.
notes_H6: Original note by Anthony Sudarmawan: As of April 6th, there was no mask mandate. However, Iowa Department of Public Health (IDPH) encouraged people to wear a face covering.   Update: http://web.archive.org/web/20210410213123/https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html   IDPH: http://web.archive.org/web/20210209110508/https://idph.iowa.gov/Emerging-Health-Issues/Novel-Coronavirus/Public     Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: Coding updated from 1G to 3T based on continuation of mask mandate in some counties in Iowa (see note on March 17 for further rationale)     Evidence of continued mask mandate in Des Moines (archived April 14):   http://web.archive.org/web/20210326051745/https://www.dsm.city/news_detail_T2_R341.php
notes_H7: A, B, C: On April 5th, the state of Iowa began to vaccinate all residents age 16 and older. Individuals aged 16 and 17 were only eligible to receive Pfizer whereas those who are 18 and older can choose between Pfizer, Moderna, or Johnson & Johnson. Due to this new policy, there will be a shortage of vaccine for several weeks.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210411093621/https://vaccinate.iowa.gov/eligibility/

name: Idaho
notes_C1: University of Idaho plans to return to in-person education starting fall 2021 while still following health guidelines for COVID-19 response.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210311065112/https://idahonews.com/news/local/idaho-state-university-oks-return-to-in-person-plan-for-fall-semester
notes_C2: Idaho remains in Stage 3: https://archive.fo/YgyCJ
notes_C3: Idaho remains in Stage 3: https://archive.fo/YgyCJ
notes_C4: Idaho remains in Stage 3: https://archive.fo/YgyCJ
notes_C5: The 1 May Stay Healthy order rescinds the 25 March Emergency Order limiting public transport use to essential services workers or to obtain essential services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200711153428/https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: https://archive.fo/zpOef
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/web/20210307154431/https:/coronavirus.idaho.gov/
notes_H3: Recent news reports confirm that Idaho's contact tracing is unable to keep up with the case load.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201129153758/https://www.ktvb.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-covid-19-case-surge-contact-tracing-health-leaders-idaho/277-90feed63-f3e9-4aff-9736-666003f8861f
notes_H6: City of Boise continues its mask order: https://archive.fo/MI9y3
notes_H7: "Starting April 5, there will be no prioritization of any group of people. All Idahoans aged 16 and older, regardless of their age, medical condition, or occupation, will be able to receive the COVID-19 vaccine."   Pfizer, Moderna, J&J    Link: https://archive.fo/g03b6

name: Illinois
notes_C1: On March 25th, West Aurora school district is offering rapid COVID-19 tests to students who show symptoms of COVID19 at school. This is to allow all levels in the school to go back to in person learning 5 days a week according to Chicago Tribune.     "The testing plan comes as West Aurora increases in-person learning to five days a week at all levels beginning April 7 in the wake of new guidance issued by the Illinois Department of Public Health which reduced social distancing guidelines from six feet to three feet. The five days of in-person learning will affect students whose families opted for the blended learning plan at the elementary, middle school and high school levels as well as for the Early Learning Academy, district officials said."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210325172623/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-aud-covid-19-pandemic-chicago-illinois-news-20210325-4ocgcgoz3nbdjdoreykedgpzv4-story.html
notes_C2: On March 25th, Mayor Lori Lightfoot loosened restrictions for outdoor activities such as baseball games, patio dining, exercise classes, weddings and concerts on Thursday, but didn’t budge on indoor capacity limits as Chicago grapples with a recent COVID19.     "Citing a worrying increase in coronavirus cases, Lightfoot said she will keep current capacity limits at indoor establishments. But bars and restaurants can now increase their maximum outdoor table size to 10 people, with tables set up so that patrons are 6 feet from patrons at other tables, the city said."     http://web.archive.org/web/20210325232314/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-coronavirus-chicago-lightfoot-further-loosens-restrictons-20210325-dlrtzsweozfnnirc77zdfwp7mq-story.html
notes_C3: All of Illinois is in Phase 4 "Revitalization" of the state's re-opening framework. In Phase 4, "All gatherings of 50 people or fewer are allowed."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322182829/https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/s/restore-illinois-phase-4
notes_C4: On March 25th, most current indoor capacity limits will remain in place across industries. Indoor capacity at bars, restaurants, social events, performance venues, seated spectator events, places of worship and other establishments will remain limited to the lesser of 50% capacity or 50 people per room or floor. In each setting, 6 feet of physical distance must be maintained among different parties, meaning that facilities may need to operate at a lower capacity to achieve 6 feet among all parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327004313/https://abc7chicago.com/covid-chicago-covid-19-reopening-restrictions/10447881/
notes_C5: No mention of closing public transit, but: People riding on public transit must comply with Social Distancing Requirements to the greatest extent feasible (stated in executive order by Governor of Illinois).   http://archive.vn/YBkdo
notes_C6: Staying at home is still implied in Chicago’s Tier 2 order.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210124040418/https://wgntv.com/news/coronavirus/city-of-chicago-to-move-to-tier-2-effective-immediately-heres-what-that-means-and-what-will-open/
notes_C7: On April 2nd, CDC updated its guideline that people who are vaccinated do not have to quarantine or get tested for COVID-19 when traveling within the United States.     "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention updated its guidance to say fully vaccinated people can travel within the U.S. without getting tested for the coronavirus or going into quarantine afterward."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402215202/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-aud-covid-19-pandemic-chicago-illinois-news-20210402-avw6ez72bvaqfhktb5e2e6byc4-story.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 5 Executive Order 2021-05 was issued, extending, among other orders, EO 2020-20, related to public assistance benefits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402150126/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx
notes_E2: On March 18, 2021, the Illinois Commerce Commission unanimously approved consumer protection agreements to help electric, natural gas, water, and sewer residential customers hard hit by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic to mitigate outstanding consumer debt and prevent disconnections before the winter moratorium on disconnections expires on March 31, 2021. Consumers struggling to pay their energy bill must call the utility to receive benefits and prevent disconnection.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402151910/https://www.icc.illinois.gov/home/covid-19
notes_H1: On March 5th, Illinois launched a public campaign to combat COVID-19 stigma in Black and Latino communities according to Chicago Tribune. Illinois is officially launched a $10 million campaign today.     "In an effort to reach Black and Latino communities that have been hard hit by the coronavirus but have lagged behind the rest of the state on vaccinations, Illinois on Friday launched a $10 million public awareness campaign to combat vaccine hesitancy."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210305222501/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-aud-covid-19-pandemic-chicago-illinois-news-20210305-muynutjis5e4pohwuffve2gk2e-story.html
notes_H2: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has several mobile testing teams that are dispatched to various locations around the state each week to provide COVID-19 testing.  Anyone can be tested, regardless of symptoms or immigration status.  There is no cost to the individual for testing, but they should bring their insurance card if they have one.  However, insurance is not required.  Specimens will be collected using a simple nasal swab.  Drive-through and walk-up testing are both available at most locations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190906/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22977
notes_H3: In Illinois, contact tracing is primarily carried out by local health department (LHD) staff. Based on contact tracing data provided by the Department of Public Health, most regions of the state have successfully interviewed at least half of all positive cases and their close contacts (positive cases: some as high as 90%; Region 11 is very low at 0.26%. Close contacts reached ranges between 44-92% across the regions).   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322191727/https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/contact-tracing-data?DV=1
notes_H6: On March 18, Gov. J.B. Pritzker reinstated that although Illinois is transitioning to full reopening, masking mandates will still be put in place and that face mask will be required until CDC recommends to not require face masks.     "Illinois will lift its face covering requirement when the CDC recommends it," Pritzker said Thursday, crediting public masking as a primary reason why the state can afford to look ahead to a new reopening phase. "Masks have been one of our best ways to reduce risk in this pandemic, and we won’t be so foolish as to throw away our best weapon heading into the last lap of the fight."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318183744/https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/illinois-face-mask-mandate-remains-as-state-looks-ahead-to-bridge-phase/2465588/
notes_H7: On April 2nd, Naperville residents are able to get vaccinated under these criteria:   "65 or older; age 18 or older with a disability or medical condition, such as obesity, diabetes, pulmonary diseases, smoking, heart conditions, chronic kidney disease, cancer, solid organ transplant, sickle cell disease or pregnancy; age 18 and older and work in the fields of health care, long-term residential care, government, news media services, higher education, food and beverage service, construction trades, religious leadership or business supporting building and infrastructure repair."     Vaccine: Johnson and Johnson     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402215202/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-aud-covid-19-pandemic-chicago-illinois-news-20210402-avw6ez72bvaqfhktb5e2e6byc4-story.html

name: Indiana
notes_C1: As of April 5, schools in Indiana are operating in-person, remote learning and a hybrid model. The  Indianapolis Public Schools will return to all in-person learning in its high schools and middle schools after spring break on April 5.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405140725/https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/indiana/articles/2021-03-06/indianapolis-public-schools-returning-to-in-person-learning
notes_C2: As of April 6th, there have been no policy changes. The CDC does not mandate or recommend closing any specific sector, but it does provide guidelines on Covid mitigation in various sectors. The CDC defers to local authorities for closures or restrictions.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214901/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232540/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: On 6 April, Gov Holcomb issued executive order 21-09 which is continuation of the county-based measures and restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. This order will last until 30 April 2021. This order states that "local health departments based on the overall spread of COVID-19 within their community or based the color-coded metric for the county, may impose measures and restrictions on gatherings and events, including limiting the size of social gatherings or event by over attendance". While local authorities may still impose restrictions, there are no longer state wide restrictions on public events as set out in previous orders.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210408031227/https://www.in.gov/gov/newsroom/executive-orders/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412153700/https://www.huschblackwell.com/indiana-state-by-state-covid-19-guidance
notes_C4: On 6 April, Gov Holcomb issued executive order 21-09 which is continuation of the county-based measures and restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. This order will last until 30 April 2021. This order states that "local health departments based on the overall spread of COVID-19 within their community or based the color-coded metric for the county, may impose measures and restrictions on gatherings and events, including limiting the size of social gatherings or event by over attendance". While local authorities may still impose restrictions on gatherings, there are no longer state wide restrictions on gatherings as set out in previous orders. Hossiers are still urged to be cautious in this executive order and to maintain social distancing around high risk individuals.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210408031227/https://www.in.gov/gov/newsroom/executive-orders/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412153700/https://www.huschblackwell.com/indiana-state-by-state-covid-19-guidance
notes_C5: As of March 29, there are no policies that are directed at closing public transport.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224943/https://www.in.gov/indot/2436.htm
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: This is the list of government relief available to businesses and employees. Source is Indiana State government.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210122185851/https://iedc.in.gov/resources/covid-19-updates-resources/home
notes_E2: As of January 4, 2021, according to the Indiana Housing & Community Development website, the rental assistance measures using federal funds were still in effect. Source: https://archive.vn/wqJ4c
notes_H1: As of April 12, Indiana is still operating a coordinated public campaign.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142551/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/
notes_H2: As of April 12, testing in Indiana is still generally available at community testing and Optum/LHI sites. You do not have to be symptomatic in order to get a test. There are also options for rapid antigen testing and testing from healthcare providers.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326211459/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/2524.htm
notes_H3: As of April 12, The Indiana Department of Health is still operating a comprehensive contact tracing system.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143159/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: As of April 5, Executive Order 21-06 issued by Governor Holcomb remains in place. On April 6, the states mask mandate will be removed but mask wearing will still be advised. Regarding face coverings it states that they must be worn:   -Inside indoor spaces open to the public nut this does not apply to private offices   -In an outdoor public space where it is not feasible to maintain 6 feet apart   -In a taxi or private car service     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210310153714/https://www.in.gov/gov/files/Executive-Order-21-06-Fourth-Extension-of-County-Based-Restrictions.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143938/https://www.indystar.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/23/indiana-covid-mask-mandate-heres-when-end/6964196002/
notes_H7: As of April 12, anyone over the age of 16 is eligible for a vaccine since the vaccination eligibility was expanded on March 31. Anyone younger than 18 must receive the Pfizer vaccine. (Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson and Johnson)     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210411060906/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/vaccine/

name: Kansas
notes_C1: On April 6th 2020, Governor Kelly signed SB63, requiring all unified school districts to 'provide a full-time, in-person attendance option for all students enrolled in kindergarten through grade 12' - Kelly claims this is already a fait accompli, stating "Currently, every school in Kansas is already offering an in-person attendance option for students.”  The University of Kansas likewise appears to be open, requiring students and staff to wear masks.   I have therefore changed the coding to 0 - No Measures, but note that it appears pupils are still permitted to study from home should they wish to, with only an in-person 'option' provided.  Kansas University Saftey Guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407180822/https://protect.ku.edu/safety-guidelines  Governor Kelly's press release: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407181017/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-signs-bill-requiring-in-person-learning-option-other-legislation/  SB63: http://www.kslegislature.org/li/b2021_22/measures/documents/sb63_enrolled.pdf
notes_C2: No obvious change in state policy as of 3rd April 2021. Closures still appear to be decided and enforced at county level. Some bars have reopened, e.g. in Sedgewick County, but the April 2020 guidance to close bars and restraunts remains up on the KDHE website.    KDHE guidance for businesess: https://web.archive.org/web/20210403155034/https://www.coronavirus.kdheks.gov/248/Business-Employers  Witchita Eagle on loosening curfews in Sedgewick County, February 26th 2021: https://web.archive.org/web/20210403155203/https://www.kansas.com/news/coronavirus/article249554428.html  Kansas City Star on easing curfews in Kansas City: https://web.archive.org/web/20210403155302/https://www.kansascity.com/news/coronavirus/article248431485.html
notes_C3: As of 27th March 2021, the Kansas State website is advertising federal funding from the Small Business Administration for venues, theatres and liver performance companies under the 'Shuttered Venue Operators Grants'    Kansas State adveritsment for the SBA SVOG: https://web.archive.org/web/20210327151526/https://covid.ks.gov/venues/
notes_C4: No apparent change in state policy, although policy appears mostly devolved to the 105 local counties. As of March 15th 2021, Lawrence-Douglas County set a limit for 50 people at mass gatherings, while Sedgewick County apparently dropped all restrictions on gatherings from April 2nd, including those at Wichita State University. Franklin County meanwhile, 'reccomends' , social distancing, mask-wearing, and avoiding mass gatherings. I am deeply unsure how to code this, but, as Douglas County has previously been listed as the most restrictive county, have changed the coding in order to align with their limit of 50 people    Lawrence-Douglas County guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408110019/https://www.ldchealth.org/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=373  KWCH12 on WSU students reacting to dropping of restrictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408110308/https://www.kwch.com/2021/04/05/wsu-students-react-to-universitys-decision-to-end-covid-19-restrictions-start-petition/  Franklin County Health Officer's thoughts: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408111411/http://www.franklincoks.org/DocumentCenter/View/15223/Thoughts-from-Dr-Bud-Ransom  Douglas County Health Order: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408111700/https://ldchealth.org/DocumentCenter/View/3612/EMERGENCY-ORDER-OF-LOCAL-HEALTH-OFFICER---March-2021---v4
notes_C5: No apparent change in policy  Kansas Department of Health Transit Recommendations: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408105320/https://www.coronavirus.kdheks.gov/DocumentCenter/View/977/What-Transit-Workers-Need-to-Know-about-COVID-19-PDF---3-15-2021
