notes_E1: On Mar. 3, Governor Laura Kelly signed a bill to protect Kansas cities from potential price surges in electricity bills caused by extremely cold temperatures in February. Senate Bill 88 establishes a $100 million low-interest loan program for municipal utilities facing high utility bills after last month’s frigid temperatures.  https://archive.fo/BdCDD
notes_E2: On April 6th, 2021, Governor Kelly announced that Kansans had now recieved funding from the KERA scheme to support rent and utilities payments. Applications remain open, but require landlord and tenant to make a joint application, along with a significant amount of documentation  Governor Kelly's Press Release: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408112736/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-kansans-are-receiving-critical-funds-for-housing-utilities/
notes_H1: On March 31st 2021, Governor Kelly's press office noted that the State 'recently launched a 'Know Before You Go' campaign to remind Kansans that testing continues to be available'  Governor Kelly's announcement: https://web.archive.org/web/20210403162604/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-no-cost-covid-19-testing-extended-through-end-of-2021/
notes_H2: Free testing remains generally available, and will until at least the end of 2021    KDHE testing page: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408112919/https://www.coronavirus.kdheks.gov/280/COVID-19-Testing  Governor Kelly's announcement about free testing: https://web.archive.org/web/20210408113318/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-no-cost-covid-19-testing-extended-through-end-of-2021/
notes_H3: Kansas claims to have spent $1.6m on contact tracing  Full details of how Kansas has spent its $1bn of the Coronavirus Relief fund can be found here, though it is extremely difficult to know how to code it: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322172010/https://covid.ks.gov/covid-data/
notes_H6: On April 1st 2021, Governor Kelly introduced a slew of executive orders extending Coronavirus policies, including the extension of the mask mandate. County-level health officials retain the power to issue more restrictive requirements, and the four Kansas First Nations Tribes retain their power to issue their own requirements. Masks may be worn outdoors where a 6-foot distance can be maintained.    Executive Order EO-21-14, with full details: /web/20210403162826/https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/EO-21-14-Executed.pdf  Governor Kelly's press release: https://web.archive.org/web/20210403163236/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-signs-executive-orders-to-maintain-covid-19-response/
notes_H7: Kansas remains in stage 5 of its vaccine plan, with vaccinations available for all over-16s   Kansas Vaccine availability page: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407185927/https://www.kansasvaccine.gov/157/Availability

name: Kentucky
notes_C1: Jefferson County Public Schools have resumed in-person learning for middle and high school students, so all students now have the option of some in-person instruction. No other school districts appear to be maintaining fully virtual instruction, so the code is moved to 1.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302223101/https://www.wave3.com/2021/03/02/jcps-unveils-hybrid-reopening-plan/
notes_C2: No detected information on the progress of the lawsuit in news media or government announcements (corrections welcome)
notes_C3: Harlan county in the red category as of April 1, prior note indicates that red zone recommendations include recommendation to cancel public events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406012917/https://www.1039thebulldog.com/2021/04/01/harlan-county-back-in-the-red-for-covid-19-cases/    “Red Zone Reduction Recommendations from the Kentucky Cabinet for Health & Family Services include having employers allow people to work from home when possible and encouraging less in-person shopping — opting for curbside pickup. Avoid non-essential activities outside your home, don’t gather, and reduce contacts.”    As of April 5, list of counties in the red zone, including link to red zone recommendations  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406013244/https://govstatus.egov.com/kycovid19    Red zone recommendations  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403082012/https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/RedCountyRecommendation.pdf
notes_C4: Discussions of Easter gatherings (religious and private, eg brunch) do not make mention of state restrictions, nor did governor press releases mention Easter restrictions, giving evidence to support no restrictions/recommendations only.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023254/https://www.wkyt.com/2021/04/02/recommendations-for-safe-easter-gatherings/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330160149/https://www.wave3.com/2021/03/29/got-easter-plans-here-is-what-you-should-know/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023533/https://governor.ky.gov/news
notes_C5: TARC remains limited to essential trips    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330083212/https://www.ridetarc.org/
notes_C6: As of April 5, several counties remain in the red zone, including link to red zone recommendations such as avoiding non-essential activities outside your home, not gathering, and reduce contacts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406013244/https://govstatus.egov.com/kycovid19    Red zone recommendations  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403082012/https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/RedCountyRecommendation.pdf
notes_C7: Recommendation to limit travel and to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival in the state remains active.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403184310/https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-travel-advisory
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: Kentucky continues to work through a backlog of 56,000 unemployment claims accrued during the pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318195425/https://www.whas11.com/article/news/investigations/focus/one-year-of-kentucky-unemployment-during-covid-pandemic/417-771953b6-1aeb-4f64-86c2-0e40b7c6686c
notes_E2: The CDC eviction moratorium, which was set to expire on March 31, has been extended to July 31, and continued to apply to residents making less than $99,000 per year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: The new "Take It From Me" campaign aims to encourage Kentucky residents wary of the vaccine to talk to relatives and friends about their experiences receiving the vaccine. The campaign includes social media, television, and print media outreach efforts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330021721/https://www.healthy-ky.org/newsroom/news-releases/article/503/take-it-from-me-new-campaign-from-kentucky-health-groups-encourages-residents-to-receive-covid-19-vaccine?
notes_H2: Widespread testing remains listed as available on state websites, including reference to state partnerships.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403213732/https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-covid-testing
notes_H3: Kentucky continues to hire for contact tracing roles, and no indication of a reduction in contact tracing was found.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210225070638/https://chfs.ky.gov/agencies/dph/covid19/contacttracingemployment.pdf
notes_H6: The mask mandate remains in place. Governor Beshear has suggested that he anticipates masks remaining mandatory through the end of May.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210316185538/https://www.wlky.com/article/beshear-we-ll-see-where-we-are-at-end-of-may-with-mask-mandate/35846062
notes_H7: As of April 5, all Kentuckians aged 16 and older are eligible for vaccination. Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson are all in use.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405224526/https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=698

name: Louisiana
notes_C1: No policy change.    LSU announced on March 19, 2021 the Office of International Programs has decided to cancel study abroad for Summer 2021.    No update on NOLA Public Schools.    unable to archive: https://www.lsu.edu/intlpro/apa/coronavirus_information/coronavirus_landingpage.php ; https://www.lsu.edu/roadmap/messages/employees.php     unable to archive: https://nolapublicschools.com/images/New%20Folder%205/Reopening_Roadmap_OnePager_070120_FINAL.pdf?type=file
notes_C2: no policy change. Louisiana remains in Phase 3. New Orleans remains in a "modified phase 3".    Effective March 24, 2021: All facilities , businesses, or operations that meet the definition of a "Commercial Body Art Facility" as defined in La. R.S. 40:2831 may continue to operate but only under a series of conditions including screening and cleaning as well as restrictions on piercing and tattoo locations: no tattoo/piercing performed in the area of the clients face covered by his/her/their mask and no piercing of nose or tongue permitted.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210328181347/https://ldh.la.gov/assets/oph/Rulemaking/er/LDH-Emergency-Order-CommercialBodyArt.pdf
notes_C3: no policy change. Louisiana remains in Phase 3. New Orleans remains in a "modified phase 3" with restrictions on gathering sizes still smaller than allowed by the state of Louisiana.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328182141/https://ready.nola.gov/incident/coronavirus/safe-reopening/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326015845/https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/29-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-RenewingCOVID-19ResilientPhase3.pdf
notes_C4: Effective April 2 for New Orleans: all indoor public and private gatherings shall be limited to 150 individuals and outdoor public and private gatherings shall be limited to 250 individuals. Also, Outdoor Recreation Spaces and Sports Complexes will be allowed to open at up to 50% of standing capacity. Indoor Recreation Spaces and Sports Complexes will be allowed to open at up to 25% of standing capacity. Any events taking place in recreation spaces or sports complexes that are not athletic competitions, must obtain a special event permit. Gov. John Bel Edwards eliminated capacity caps in the rest of Louisiana on bars, restaurants, fitness centers and other businesses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407192659/https://www.nola.com/news/coronavirus/article_71fdb652-9267-11eb-9973-f359162e6630.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407195239/https://ready.nola.gov/incident/coronavirus/update/city-adjusts-gathering-size-and-capacity-limits-un/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404093920/https://ready.nola.gov/incident/coronavirus/safe-reopening/
notes_C5: no policy change.
notes_C6: no policy change.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210326015845/https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/29-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-RenewingCOVID-19ResilientPhase3.pdf
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: no policy change.
notes_E2: no policy change.
notes_H1: no policy change.
notes_H2: no policy change. The Louisiana Department of Health recommends COVID-19 testing for any patients who are experiencing symptoms such as fever, cough or shortness of breath. If you have these symptoms or believe you may have been exposed to someone with COVID-19, contact your primary care physician for guidance. However, you do not have to be experiencing symptoms to be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405154159/https://ldh.la.gov/index.cfm/page/3934?clearCache=1
notes_H3: no policy change.
notes_H6: no policy change. Statewide mask mandate remains in effect.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210326015845/https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/29-JBE-2021-State-of-Emergency-RenewingCOVID-19ResilientPhase3.pdf
notes_H7: no policy change.     The Louisiana Public Health Institute (LPHI) and Louisiana Department of Health (LDH) are hosting a series of virtual community conversations called “All Things Covid-19 Vaccine — A Tele-Townhall for Sharing Information and Answers.” Each event will be moderated by Shelina Davis, CEO of LPHI, and Dr. Earl Benjamin-Robinson, Director of LDH’s Office of Community Partnerships & Health Equity. Local panelists will include each region’s medical director, faith-based leaders and community advocates.  The goal of these events is to provide information about the COVID-19 vaccine, dispel myths and answer direct questions from participants. The dialogue will also focus on equitable health outcomes for all Louisianans, especially the African American community who has been disproportionately impacted by COVID-19.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405132018/https://ldh.la.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/6094

name: Massachusetts
notes_C1: "Many public schools are bringing their youngest students back to the classroom full-time beginning today, under a plan from Gov. Charlie Baker and his top education officials. It’s important to note students can opt to keep learning remotely for now, and many already had some in-person class time through hybrid learning. "    "All elementary schools in the state are slated to be fully in person by May 3 as districts transition from COVID-19 related learning models to five days a week of in-person school.    The Department of Elementary and Secondary Education laid out a timeline calling for public schools to offer five days a week of in-person learning for K-5 students by April 5 and for grade 6-8 students by April 28. Districts are encouraged to plan for a return to in-person learning for pre-kindergarten as soon as possible. While parents can opt to keep their children home for the remainder of the school year, districts were asked to stick to that timeline or request a waiver."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410192944/https://www.politico.com/newsletters/massachusetts-playbook/2021/04/05/back-to-school-new-group-can-get-vaccine-today-questions-linger-in-soldiers-home-tragedy-492353    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409103945/https://www.masslive.com/coronavirus/2021/03/all-massachusetts-elementary-schools-will-be-fully-in-person-by-may-3-state-says.html
notes_C2: No change. Still in Phase IV, Step 1.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210408195824/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/reopening-massachusetts    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409064406/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/reopening-when-can-my-business-reopen
notes_C3: No change.     "On March 1, Massachusetts loosened capacity restrictions for several industries and advanced to Step 2 of Phase III of the reopening plan. Since then, hospitalizations dropped by 20% and deaths dropped by 24%. The seven day average of new cases in long-term care facilities dropped by 53%. The positive test rate remains below 2% and has been for several weeks now. The seven day average of new cases is also down over this time by 7%.     Effective Monday, March 22, all communities in Massachusetts will move into Step 1 of Phase IV of the state’s reopening plan. This will open a range of previously closed business sectors under tight capacity restrictions that are expected to be adjusted over time if favorable trends in the public health data continue. Effective on the planned advancement to Step 1 of Phase IV, the following large capacity sports and entertainment venues will be permitted to operate at a strict 12% capacity limit after submitting a plan to the Department of Public Health (DPH):    Indoor and outdoor stadiums  Arenas  Ballparks  Also effective on March 22, gathering limits for event venues and in public settings will increase to 100 people indoors and 150 people outdoors. Outdoor gatherings at private residences and in private backyards will remain at a maximum of 25 people, with indoor house gatherings remaining at 10 people.    Additionally, dance floors will be permitted at weddings and other events only, and overnight summer camps will be allowed to operate this coming summer. Exhibition and convention halls may also begin to operate, following gatherings limits and event protocols. Other Phase IV sectors must continue to remain closed."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410193852/https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-announces-transition-to-phase-iv-of-reopening-plan
notes_C4: No change.    "Also effective on March 22, gathering limits for event venues and in public settings will increase to 100 people indoors and 150 people outdoors. Outdoor gatherings at private residences and in private backyards will remain at a maximum of 25 people, with indoor house gatherings remaining at 10 people."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410193852/https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-announces-transition-to-phase-iv-of-reopening-plan
notes_C5: No change.    "Due to the COVID-19 outbreak, many transit authorities have made adaptations to their regular routes, schedules, and procedures. If you plan to make a trip by public transit, please check your transit authority's website or social media accounts to get the most up-to-date information.    In accordance with the Governor's Order, all passengers over age 5 must wear a face mask while riding public transit and paratransit services, with exceptions made for certain medical conditions and disabilities. Masks are also recommended for passengers ages 2 through 5."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410194054/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/public-transportation-in-massachusetts
notes_C6: No evidence of new stay at home advisory/requirements.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403183341/https://www.nbcboston.com/news/coronavirus/baker-to-tour-gillette-vaccination-site-give-update-on-covid-business-relief-program/2284373/
notes_C7: No change.    "As of Monday, March 22, all visitors entering Massachusetts, including returning residents, are advised to quarantine for 10 days upon their arrival.  Travelers in the following categories are exempt from this quarantine advisory:    Travelers who have received a negative COVID-19 result on a test administered not more than 72 hours prior to their arrival in Massachusetts.  Travelers may also test out of the quarantine advisory after arrival in Massachusetts, as long as they quarantine until receiving a negative test result.  Anyone who is entering Massachusetts for fewer than 24 hours  Anyone who is returning to Massachusetts after being out of the State for fewer than 24 hours  Workers who enter Massachusetts to perform critical infrastructure functions (as specified by the Federal Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency) during required commuting to or from work and while at work.  Travelers who are fully vaccinated (i.e. who have received two doses of either the Moderna or Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines OR who have received a single dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 14 days or more ago) and who do not have symptoms.    All travelers are encouraged to consult and follow the CDC’s guidelines and requirements for travel."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409170011/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-advisory
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: No change.    "In an effort to protect Massachusetts ratepayers struggling with the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Department of Public Utilities (DPU) today issued an Order extending the moratorium on residential gas, electric, and water utility shutoffs to July 1, 2021. The moratorium, previously scheduled to end in April, will deliver temporary financial relief for ratepayers while providing additional time for ratepayers to coordinate a payment plan with a utility company and explore the availability of financial assistance programs."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403184843/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/financial-assistance-during-the-covid-19-crisis    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403184801/https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-extends-utility-shutoff-moratorium
notes_H1: No change.    "Trust the Facts. Get the Vax." campaign began Feb 7 and will run for the next 5 months.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410202015/https://www.mass.gov/doc/campaign-summary-trust-the-facts-get-the-vax/download    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410201913/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/trust-the-facts-get-the-vax-campaign-materials
notes_H2: Visit Find a COVID-19 Test to search for a testing site near you.    Many sites may require pre-screening, a referral and/or an appointment. Please contact the site prior to arrival.    Learn about the free drive-through Express COVID-19 Testing Sites in Massachusetts.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210408200254/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/about-covid-19-testing
notes_H3: No change.    "The Commonwealth of Massachusetts created the COVID-19 Community Tracing program to help support local health departments from every community in their contact tracing work. The program focuses on reaching out to people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and the contacts they have been close to, making sure they have the support they need to isolate or quarantine. When the MA COVID Team calls, you can do your part by answering the phone and providing helpful information that will help flatten and reduce the curve in Massachusetts."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410202551/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/learn-about-the-community-tracing-collaborative
notes_H6: No change.    "Governor Baker issued an Order effective November 6, 2020 requiring face masks or cloth face coverings in all public places, whether indoors or outdoors, even where they are able to maintain 6 feet of distance from others. Masks or face coverings are encouraged but not required for children between the ages of 2 and 5. Read the full DPH Guidance and Frequently Asked Questions.    The revised order still allows for an exception for residents who cannot wear a face-covering due to a medical or disabling condition, but it allows employers to require employees to provide proof of such a condition. It also allows schools to require that students participating in in-person learning provide proof of such a medical or disabling condition."    Exceptions for vaccinated individuals:  "You may visit with other fully vaccinated people indoors in private settings without wearing masks or physical distancing. For example, if you are fully vaccinated, it is likely a low risk for you to invite other fully vaccinated friends to dinner inside your home."    "The Massachusetts Department of Public Health recommends following CDC guidance which says you may visit in a private setting indoors with unvaccinated people from a single household who are at low risk of severe COVID-19 disease without wearing masks or physical distancing."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409174630/https://www.mass.gov/news/mask-up-ma    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408143148/https://www.mass.gov/guidance/guidance-for-people-who-are-fully-vaccinated-against-covid-19
notes_H7: No change.    A,B,C: A- Key workers, B- Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), C- Elderly groups    Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are being administered.    "Phase 1  (December 2020 – February 2021)    Listed in order of priority:    Clinical and non-clinical health care workers doing direct and COVID-facing care  Long term care facilities, rest homes and assisted living facilities  First responders   Congregate care settings  Home-based health care workers  Health care workers doing non-COVID-facing care  Phase 2  Currently Eligible:    People who are 75 or older  People who are 55 or older  People with 1 or more certain medical conditions  People who live or work in low income and affordable senior housing  K-12 educators, K-12 school staff, and child care workers  Certain workers"    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409055116/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-covid-19-vaccination-phases    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409055609/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-vaccine-frequently-asked-questions    List of "certain workers"  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409055525/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-vaccinations-for-certain-workers

name: Maryland
notes_C1: As of March 25, the State of Maryland is adopting new guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommending that, with universal masking in place, students should maintain a distance of at least three feet in classroom settings.    This updated guidance is the result of numerous and robust academic studies finding that 3 ft of distance between students did not significantly impact transmission of COVID-19 when compared to the earlier 6 ft distancing guidance. Adults should continue to maintain 6 ft distance from students and other adults.    Website here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210326202149/https://governor.maryland.gov/2021/03/25/state-of-maryland-adopts-cdcs-updated-physical-distancing-guidelines-for-k-12-schools/
notes_C2: As of 15th February 2021, Executive Order 21-01-28-01 remains in effect (see previous note in this indicator). Therefore, this indicator remains at 1G.     Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210207221714/https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Gatherings-18th-AMENDED-01.28.21.pdf    https://archive.vn/UV1ri
notes_C3: Effective Friday, March 12 at 5pm, large outdoor and indoor venues may begin operating at 50% capacity. This includes theaters; concert, convention, and wedding venues; racing facilities, and outdoor entertainment and sporting venues. Website here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315192804/https://governor.maryland.gov/recovery/
notes_C4: Effective Friday, March 12 at 5pm, capacity limits will be lifted on outdoor and indoor dining at restaurants and bars, retail businesses, religious facilities, fitness centers, casinos, personal services, and indoor recreational establishments. Bars and restaurants will be open for seated and distanced service only—patrons may not stand at a crowded bar. Masking and distancing rules remain in place. Code remains 3T to reflect that capacity limits are lifted at above venues and increased to 50% at large indoor/outdoor venues. Website here:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210315192804/https://governor.maryland.gov/recovery/
notes_C5: Executive Order 21-01-28-01, linked below, confirms that facial coverings are still required in all public spaces in the state of Maryland, including passengers using public transit.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210128203242/https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Gatherings-18th-AMENDED-01.28.21.pdf
notes_C6: As of 15th February, Executive Order 20-12-17-01, which urges Marylanders to limit travel to essential trips, is still in effect. Therefore, this indicator remains at 1G.     Source: https://archive.vn/MHrGh
notes_C7: As of March 12, Governor Larry Hogan announced Quarantine requirements and other restrictions on out-of-state travel will be lifted. A Maryland Department of Health (MDH) travel advisory will remain in place, and Marylanders continue to be encouraged to get tested for COVID-19 upon their return from out-of-state travel. Website here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315192804/https://governor.maryland.gov/recovery/
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7." notes_H2: As of 15th February 2021, there have been no updates to Maryland's testing policy or capabilities. Therefore this indicator remains at 3.
notes_H3: As of 15th February, contact tracing is still limited in Maryland, with only 1400 contact tracers and a 7-day average daily case rate of over 1,000. Therefore this indicator remains at 1.     Sources: https://archive.vn/8M2qT    https://archive.vn/hcaGp

notes_H7: Governor Larry Hogan today announced that all Marylanders age 16 and older can now pre-register for an appointment to receive a COVID-19 vaccine at a mass vaccination site. Nearly 300,000 Marylanders have already successfully pre-registered.    While pre-registration is now open to all Marylanders, individuals who are currently eligible under Phase 1 and Phase 2 but have not yet been vaccinated will continue to be prioritized for appointments. name: Missouri
notes_C1: On March 24, the University of Missouri published a press release about workers. Dear University faculty and staff,    Throughout this last year, you have proven yourselves resilient in a time of great uncertainty and steady change. We so appreciate your willingness to step up and keep us going.    Thankfully, effective – and increasingly available – COVID-19 vaccines, along with a decrease in active cases in our region, usher in new possibilities for how we can interact.    Next Monday (March 29), all of you, as higher education faculty and staff (including student employees), will be eligible to receive a COVID-19 vaccine. We strongly encourage you to sign up for a vaccine appointment. Please see our vaccine page here for links to options, which includes information to make an appointment as dates become available at our Faurot Field vaccine site. There, dedicated MU Health Care teams have already vaccinated nearly 23,000 people.    Over the last several months, many of you safely returned to in-person work, following our COVID-19 guidelines. Meanwhile in our community, public schools have announced plans to shift to full in-person attendance in early April and this week, Boone County relaxed public health orders. We expect this progress to continue as we approach fall and our plans to resume full-capacity classes and activities here at Mizzou.    As another step toward resuming our pre-pandemic lives, we ask faculty and staff who have not yet returned to in-person work to do so by May 17. Faculty on 9-month appointments without duties over the summer should plan to return in August. We are sending this message in advance to give you and your supervisor time to make a transition plan if needed.    As more faculty and staff return, we remain committed to sustaining a safe community. Social distancing and face covering requirements will continue until public health guidance changes. Supervisors will need to ensure work settings meet office safety expectations and consult with Campus Facilities if work spaces need modification.    We know ongoing efforts to maximize our resources, including the recent announcement to close buildings, mean some in-person offices will not be the same. In addition, we realize, in some settings, social distancing is not possible with a full in-person return and that factor should be considered in any transition plan. If you witness an unsafe situation at work related to our COVID-19 protocols, you should let your supervisor know or submit a concern here.    Through this transition, we expect to retain some of our COVID-era practices, as we found some enhanced our work. In some circumstances, supervisors may decide flexible work arrangements will best fit the environment and the work needed to support the university’s mission. If so, your supervisor will initiate, revise or extend a telework arrangement. The form is available on our Working Through COVID-19 webpage and will need to be submitted by May 17.    We know our Tigers are anxious to enjoy a “more normal” experience in the fall, which will of course adhere to the advice of our medical experts, local public health officials, and CDC guidance. Our Show Me Renewal site will stay current with any changes along the way. There, you can also find the latest updates on the process for planning events. We see this step as a sign of hope for our university as we return to more in-person activity to serve our students, our community, and our state.    Thank you to everyone for your tremendous efforts during this extraordinary time. We are grateful to reach this point and for the rest of our community to join us on our beautiful campus.    Tigers Support Tigers!    Mun Choi, Ph.D.  President, University of Missouri    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330134539/https://president.missouri.edu/messages/full-in-person-work-return-by-5-17/

(50% capacity for most businesses, 25% capacity for large venues)  https://archive.fo/hPLLl

It continues to recommend that people minimize gatherings with people outside of their households.  https://archive.fo/hPLLl

The latest pandemic-related executive order was enacted on November 19, 2020.    Executive Orders: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125122922/https://governor.mo.gov/actions/executive-orders   Legislative Actions: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125123621/https://governor.mo.gov/actions/legislative-actions   Proclamations: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125123830/https://governor.mo.gov/actions/proclamations

US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 19,oday, Governor Mike Parson announced that the Missouri Department of Revenue is extending the state individual tax filing and payment deadline for the 2020 tax year from April 15, 2021, to May 17, 2021.    “As our state continues recovering from COVID-19, we understand that many Missourians are still feeling the effects of the past year,” Governor Parson said. “Extending the filing and payment deadline by one month will provide additional relief to Missouri families and tax professionals as they work to meet their obligations during what has already been a challenging tax season.”      This decision mirrors Wednesday’s announcement by the U.S. Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) that individual taxpayers would receive automatic extensions to file and pay federal income tax for the 2020 tax year. The IRS has said it will issue formal guidance in the coming days.    The Department of Revenue will automatically provide this filing and payment relief, so filers do not need to take any action to qualify.    Guidance on extension to file and pay individual income tax:    Filing deadline extended: The deadline to file individual income tax returns has been extended from April 15, 2021, to May 17, 2021.  Payment relief for individuals: The deadline to pay taxes owed on individual income tax returns with a due date of April 15, 2021, has been extended until May 17, 2021.  This relief applies to individual taxpayers, including those who pay self-employment tax. However, it does not apply to estimated tax payments that are due on April 15, 2021; that deadline has not changed.  Penalties and interest will begin to accrue on any remaining unpaid balances as of May 17, 2021. Individuals that file their return and pay their balance by May 17, 2021, will automatically avoid interest and penalties on the tax paid by May 17.  Customers may still ask for an extension of time to file their individual income taxes. With that extension, the return will not be due until October 15, 2021. However, any payments must still be made by May 17, 2021.  Earlier this year, the IRS announced that the nation’s 2021 electronic tax filing season would begin on February 12. On that date, the IRS began accepting and processing e-filed 2020 tax year returns. Since e-filed state returns are first sent to the IRS, the Department also began accepting and processing e-filed returns for the 2020 tax year on February 12.    “With a delayed start and recent tax code changes, this tax season is a particularly complicated one,” said Director of Revenue Ken Zellers. “For Missourians who have yet to file, we strongly encourage you to file electronically and use direct deposit, as it will result in the most accurate return and the fastest refund. We appreciate your patience as we navigate this tax season together, and we stand ready to assist you in any way we can.”    Department of Revenue online services and resources:    The Department’s Tax Return Status Tracker allows customers to enroll in automatic text and email alerts that are sent each time the status of their return is updated. Customers need their Social Security number, filing status, and anticipated refund or balance due to enroll and must re-enroll each year.  Get answers 24/7 by reviewing the Personal Tax FAQs or with the help of the Department’s chatbot, DORA, a virtual assistant programmed to respond to common taxation, motor vehicle, and driver licensing questions.  Email questions to income@dor.mo.gov.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326185020/https://governor.mo.gov/press-releases/archive/governor-parson-announces-individual-tax-filing-and-payment-deadline
notes_E2: Mayor Lyda Krewson today announced that City of St. Louis residents who need help staying in their homes and keeping their utilities on during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic can apply for rental and utility assistance through the State of Missouri beginning Thursday, April 1. Since two major cities have rental assistance in place (St. Louis & Kansas City), I have changed the coding from 0 “None” to 1 “Narrow” relief.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405130357/https://www.stlouis-mo.gov/government/departments/mayor/news/rental-utility-assistance-apr-2021.cfm https://archive.fo/O7oVh
notes_H1: On March 24, the Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS), with the support of the Missouri Advisory Committee on Equitable COVID-19 Vaccine Distribution, launched a new statewide transportation guide to help address and eliminate barriers to COVID-19 vaccine access. This guide is the result of efforts made to increase access to free and low-cost transportation resources across Missouri’s rural, suburban and urban communities to administer the COVID-19 vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405133445/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/2ada5c68-c2ac-42a9-b4cd-b26282b56123/missouri-launches-new-statewide-transportation-resource-guide-to-expand-covid-19-vaccine-access-to-rural-suburban-and-urban-communities-across-the-state
notes_H2: As of April 6, Missouri has set up a weekly Covid-19 testing schedule Mondays through Saturdays & some select Sundays, no pre-registration or appointment needed.  https://archive.fo/clleZ
notes_H3: On February 26, the Missouri Department of Health & Senior Service published that variants of the COVID-19 virus continue to develop around the world, and scientists in the United States and around the world continue to monitor them for their characteristics as they relate to infectivity, morbidity and response to available vaccines and treatments. At this time, the most concerning virus variants are required to be reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): those that have emerged from the United Kingdom (known as 20I/501Y.V1, VOC 202012/01, or B.1.1.7), South Africa (known as 20H/501Y.V2 or B.1.351) and Brazil (known as 20J/501Y.V3 or P.1). To date, one person has been identified as having the UK variant in Missouri and none with the South African or Brazilian variant. At least 45 states have reported at least one case of the UK variant to the CDC.    Missouri is a national thought leader for its use of sewage analysis to study the prevalence of COVID-19 virus within samples from around the state to monitor prevalence and trends in an aggregated manner. Working with the University of Missouri and Missouri Department of Natural Resources, the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS) recently widened its capacity to do coronavirus viral sequencing to also look at sewage samples from around the state to further enhance surveillance for existing and emerging variants.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302011210/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/d831a879-4f93-4b30-a0a0-214d6cd55662/state-continues-to-monitor-covid-19-variant-viruses
notes_H6: As of April 4, the latest mask order in effect in St. Louis County is the Third Amended Order Requiring Members of the Public and Employees to Wear Face Coverings (Nov. 18, 2020). It requires masks to be worn at indoor and outdoor public spaces.  https://archive.fo/RISF5  As of April 4, the latest mask order in effect in Kansas City is the Twelfth Amended Order (Jan. 13, 2021), which continues to require face coverings in indoor and outdoor public spaces.  https://archive.fo/mgM4y
notes_H7: On March 29, as Phase 2 of Missouri's COVID-19 Vaccination Plan opens today, extending COVID-19 vaccine eligibility to approximately 880,000 Missourians, Governor Mike Parson applauds the continued efforts of state-supported vaccination teams and other community vaccine providers across the state.     "Today marks the activation of Phase 2 of our state's Vaccination Plan, and I cannot thank our Missouri National Guard, DHSS, and FEMA personnel as well as our countless state, local, and private partners enough for their efforts," Governor Parson said. "With nearly 3.9 million adult Missourians now eligible, we have come a long way since vaccines first arrived in Missouri. This has truly been a team effort and will continue to be as we keep making progress toward our goal of providing every Missourian the opportunity for a vaccine."    The activation of Phase 2 will extend vaccine eligibility to approximately 880,000 additional adult Missourians. In total, an estimated 3.9 million adult Missourians are eligible and activated for a COVID-19 vaccine.     Phase 2 includes Missourians who are essential to equitable economic recovery, including those employed in construction, critical manufacturing, higher education, and remaining food and agriculture sectors. This also includes homeless and disproportionately affected populations with an emphasis on racial and ethnic minorities, among others.      In just three days last week, more than 20,000 initial COVID-19 vaccine doses were administered in the St. Louis area through state-supported vaccination events alone. This does not include thousands of doses that were administered by various other community providers in the area.     At the state's two-day Mega Vaccination Event at St. Louis Community College – Forest Park, 6,600 Missourians were fully vaccinated with the Janssen vaccine. The state-supported clinics at The Family Arena in St. Charles and Greensfelder Recreation Complex at Queeny Park administered 9,000 and over 4,450 initial doses, respectively.     To date, Missouri providers have administered more than 2.34 million total doses of the COVID-19 vaccine to Missourians across the state. More than 1.5 million Missourians, nearly 25 percent, have received an initial vaccine dose, and more than 875,000 have been fully vaccinated.     Additionally, data shows that nearly 40 percent of the approximately three million Missourians who were eligible prior to Phase 2 have initiated vaccination. According to CDC data, which includes the latest doses administered through federal partnerships, nearly 66 percent of  Missouri's 65 and older population and 32 percent of  its 18 and older population have received an initial vaccination.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210330144449/https://governor.mo.gov/press-releases/archive/governor-parson-applauds-vaccination-efforts-phase-two-covid-19-vaccine-plan

notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/

notes_H2: According to the Mississippi Department of Health website, all Mississippi residents “can be tested for COVID-19 by local medical providers statewide, or at free testing sites held at various locations around the state. Some providers may require that you have qualifying symptoms before testing.”    There is testing available to college and university students, faculty, or staff, as well as child care facility workers regardless if they are asymptomatic or have symptoms of COVID-19.    Coded as 2 to reflect the policy that anyone who has COVID-19 symptoms can be tested, and that there are many testing centers at which residents can do so.    Link to testing policy page on MS Department of Health site: https://web.archive.org/web/20210215193055/https://msdh.ms.gov/msdhsite/_static/14,21912,420,874.html  ?Link to special testing groups for COVID-19:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210216005301/https://msdh.ms.gov/msdhsite/_static/14,22406,420,874.html
notes_H3: Once again, no indication of expansion or reduction in contact tracing efforts was found. Open to revision  Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:  Contact tracing appears to be very limited in Mississippi. There is no dedicated contact tracing page or information available on the MS Department of Health website. According to news articles, it appears that contact tracing is mainly done in universities and in college/professional sporting teams/events if someone tests positive for COVID-19.  Link to news article on inadequate contact tracing (12 July 2020) https://web.archive.org/web/20210125135309/https://mississippitoday.org/2020/07/12/the-trouble-with-contact-tracing-in-mississippi/ Link to news article on contact tracing at the University of Mississippi (24 August 2020): https://web.archive.org/web/20201022123233/https://news.olemiss.edu/universitys-contact-tracing-efforts-strengthened-by-smartphone-app/

notes_H7: As of March 20, vaccine appointments are available to all Mississippi residents.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210317171504/https://www.ft.com/content/bd734008-9355-42f3-a0dc-38988d5a9a67#post-e2cfc0fe-1b7a-4d12-9c16-673d538ff64e

name: North Carolina
notes_C1: As of 5th April 2021, the Strong Schools NC Public Health Toolkit (last updated 24th March 2021) is still drawing a distinction between Plan A and Plan B strategies. All schools, no matter which plan they are following, are required to "discontinue in-person activities that involve bringing together large groups of people or activities that do not allow for physical distancing (assemblies, performances, field trips etc)." With this in mind, this indicator remains at 1T.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210404093959/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/media/164/download
notes_C2: Executive Order 204, which came into effect on 26th March 2021, relaxes occupancy restrictions of businesses to:     "100% for museums, aquariums, retail businesses and shops, barbershops, salons    75% indoors and outdoors for restaurants, breweries, wineries, amusement parks, gyms, pools    50% indoors and outdoors for bars, conference centers, reception venues, sports arenas, other live performance venues"    This indicator still remains at 1G, to reflect ongoing social distancing/face covering measures in North Carolina workplaces.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405192521/https://www.nc.gov/covid-19/staying-ahead-curve
notes_C3: Executive Order 204, which restricts the capacity of sports arenas, concert venues, and other live performance venues to 50%, comes into effect at 5pm on 26th March 2021. Given that some public events will (presumably) still have to be postponed or rearranged due to these restrictions, this indicator remains at 1G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405192521/https://www.nc.gov/covid-19/staying-ahead-curve
notes_C4: On 26th March 2021, Executive Order 204 came into effect. This lifts the limit on indoor gatherings to 50 and outdoor gatherings to 100. This indicator remains at 3G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405192521/https://www.nc.gov/covid-19/staying-ahead-curve
notes_C5: According to the GoRaleigh website, Raleigh's public transport system is running as of 5th April 2021. The 1G rating of this indicator therefore reflects ongoing face covering requirements, as well as the temporary suspension of the R-Line bus service.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405202555/https://goraleigh.org/news/goraleigh-related-covid-19-information
notes_C6: North Carolina's latest County Alert graded zero counties as red, 21 as orange, one as green, and the rest as yellow. Individuals in red and orange counties are advised to stay home, but they are not required by law to do so. Given these changes, this indicator now moves to 1T.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210404094544/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/media/868/download
notes_C7: North Carolina's latest County Alert, published on 1st April 2021, advises residents to "delay domestic or international travel". None of the counties were coded as red in the last update; 21 are coded as orange, one green, and the rest yellow. Therefore this indicator remains at 1G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210404094544/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/media/868/download
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: As of 29th March 2021 (when the webpage was last updated), the NCDHHS's COVID-19 Support Services Program was "winding down, which means no new services can be requested". As the programme has not yet been confirmed to have stopped entirely, this indicator remains at 1F.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405204435/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/information/human-services/support-services-program
notes_E2: On 30th March 2021, Governor Roy Cooper extended the statewide moratorium on evictions until 30th June 2021. Therefore this indicator remains at 2 until at least this date.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405170726/https://governor.nc.gov/news/governor-cooper-signs-three-executive-orders-help-struggling-north-carolinians-and-boost
notes_H1: North Carolina's ongoing public information campaign can be seen in, among other initiatives, the NCDHHS's video series on the importance of getting the COVID-19 vaccine, which features local celebrities.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405195102/https://www.ncdhhs.gov/news/press-releases/richard-petty-covid-19-vaccines-%E2%80%9Cyou-have-spot-take-your-shot%E2%80%9D    http://web.archive.org/web/20210405195226/https://www.ncdhhs.gov/news/press-releases/north-carolina-ncaa-basketball-coaches-covid-19-vaccines-%E2%80%9Cyou-have-spot-take
notes_H2: There have been no official updates to North Carolina's testing policy or capabilities since 4th March 2021; however, as of 5th April, it appears that the state's testing centres are working well. It is still specified that you should get a test "if you are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 or have been exposed to the virus".     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405195447/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/about-covid-19/testing/find-my-testing-place
notes_H3: As of 5th April 2021, there have been no updates to North Carolina's contact tracing policy or capabilities since 26th February 2021. However, it appears that the SlowCOVIDNC app is still being used for contact tracing.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405195834/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/slow-spread/slowcovidnc-app
notes_H6: As of 5th April 2021, Executive Order 204, which requires the wearing of face coverings in all public indoor settings, will remain in effect until at least 30th April. Therefore this indicator remains at 3G.       Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405192521/https://www.nc.gov/covid-19/staying-ahead-curve
notes_H7: On 31st March 2021, North Carolina began vaccinating the rest of Group 4: all remaining frontline workers and adults in close group living settings (homeless, incarcerated, etc). This indicator therefore remains at 3G.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405193939/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/vaccines/find-your-spot-take-your-shot/deeper-dive-group-4    http://web.archive.org/web/20210405174349/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/vaccines    http://web.archive.org/web/20210405194226/https://governor.nc.gov/news/governor-cooper-announces-accelerated-timeline-vaccination-eligibility

Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: North Dakota Department of Health continues to share information regarding COVID-19 cases, testing and vaccines on its media platforms    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411231100/https://twitter.com/NDDOH/status/1379102999646199811
notes_H2: North Dakota Health Department's website continues to provide information regarding availability of free COVID-19 testing    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411232223/https://www.health.nd.gov/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/testing-care/where-get-covid-19-test
notes_H3: Advice for people traced as close contacts: https://web.archive.org/web/20210313125515/https://www.health.nd.gov/what-do-if-you-are-close-contact
notes_H6: As of March 30th, masks are still required on all federal buildings/lands and by all federal contractors. They are also required on public transit and in all transit hubs.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329182206/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-the-federal-workforce-and-requiring-mask-wearing/    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210404205822/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/face-masks-public-transportation.html
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson's    North Dakota Department of Health announced that on March 29th the state’s COVID-19 vaccine rollout reaches Phase 2 opening access to the vaccine to all North Dakotans over age 16 therefore the code has been updated to 4G    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405053211/https://twitter.com/NDDOH/status/1376630519492976642

name: Nebraska
notes_C1: As of March 28, all counties in Nebraska are still in the Green Zone, so schools should be open. Many schools in major cities have moved to in-person learning.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322114236/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/DHM-Measure-Table-ENGLISH.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210329152716/https://district.ops.org/DEPARTMENTS/General-Finance-and-Administrative-Services/District-Communications/In-Person-Learning https://web.archive.org/web/20210329153214/https://www.1011now.com/2021/01/22/lps-seniors-can-return-to-full-in-person-learning-next-month/
notes_C2: As of April 6th, there have been no policy changes. The CDC does not mandate or recommend closing any specific sector, but it does provide guidelines on Covid mitigation in various sectors. The CDC defers to local authorities for closures or restrictions.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214901/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232540/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: As of April 6th, the CDC recommends against large gatherings. Guidelines are provided for exposure mitigation in congregate settings.
