notes_C4: As of March 28, all counties in Nebraska are still in the Green Zone. There are no gathering restrictions. Venues with the capacity to host 500 or more people are required to submit plans to local health departments to be approved in advance.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322114236/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/DHM-Measure-Table-ENGLISH.pdf
notes_C5: no policy change.
notes_C6: As of March 28, the Nebraska Department of Health & Human Services continues to recommend staying at home and working from home, except for essential activities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329153531/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Protect-Yourself-and-Others.aspx
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On April 6th, the governor of Nebraska discussed about rental assistance.    We want to remind landlords and tenants about the Emergency Rental Assistance Program available to help with rent and utilities for eligible tenants who are struggling with rent or utility payments due to COVID-19 related financial hardship.  When the State kicked off its program on February 22nd, we noted that Lancaster County, Douglas County, Lincoln, and Omaha were all covered under separate programs, which had not yet launched.  As of today, we are pleased to announce that the City of Lincoln and Lancaster County programs are live.  The City of Omaha’s emergency rental assistance program is also live as of today, April 5th.  The Douglas County program is planning to launch sometime during mid-April.  The links to these programs can be found at coronavirus.nebraska.gov/EmergencyRentalAssistanceProgram.   Applicants living outside of Lancaster and Douglas counties should apply through the State’s website at coronavirus.nebraska.gov.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210408155738/https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-urges-nebraskans-get-their-coronavirus-vaccination
notes_E2: The CDC eviction moratorium and the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) are still in place (until March 31).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322114912/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Energy-Assistance.aspx
notes_H1: On April 6, the governor of Nebraska expresses this pandemic has been difficult for the Hispanic community, just as it has for all Nebraskans.  Many frontline workers in hospitals and meat-packing plants have continued to work, despite the risk, to keep Nebraska running.  As a result, a disproportionate number of Hispanics have suffered from the effects of the virus.  Since the vaccine became available, DHHS has partnered with several organizations to reach out to the Hispanic community to provide information about the importance and safety of the vaccine.  This has included town halls in Spanish with the Multicultural Coalition in Grand Island, the Mexican Consulate in Omaha, and a statewide outreach with Telemundo Nebraska.  The website to sign up for vaccination is vaccinate.ne.gov.  On the website in the top right corner, you can switch the language from English to Spanish.  Anyone can call the info line to get registered toll free: 833-998-2275.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210408155738/https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-urges-nebraskans-get-their-coronavirus-vaccination
notes_H2: As of March 28, tests are still widely available through the TestNebraska website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329153818/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Testing.aspx
notes_H3: no policy change.
notes_H6: As of March 30th, masks are still required on all federal buildings/lands and by all federal contractors. They are also required on public transit and in all transit hubs.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329182206/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-the-federal-workforce-and-requiring-mask-wearing/    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210404205822/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/face-masks-public-transportation.html
notes_H7: On March 31,Gov. Ricketts also announced that all health districts in Nebraska will move into Phase 2B of the state’s vaccination plan as of April 5, 2021.  Phase 2B includes state residents age 16-49.    I want to remind folks that we’re still in a pandemic, even with the increasing amount of vaccines coming into Nebraska.  Please continue to use our tools to slow the spread of the virus, such as staying home when sick and washing hands often.  We’ve now administered over 868,000 vaccinations.  Nebraskans can sign up for vaccination at vaccinate.ne.gov or by calling 833-998-2275.  All local health departments moved to Phase 2A on March 22, 2021.  In Phase 2A, we’re prioritizing Nebraskans age 50-64 to receive at least 90% of vaccines.  In Phase 2A, local health departments are also working with health providers in their area to prioritize Nebraskans whose underlying health conditions put them at increased risk from the virus.  The federal vaccine program has expanded to all adults age 18 and older.  As vaccine supplies increase, we’re quickly expanding access through the state’s vaccination program as well.  Some local health departments have already opened up vaccination to any adult in their district.  As of Monday, April 5th, the entire state will move to Phase 2B, which includes all Nebraskans age 16-49.  This does not mean that every health district will immediately be able to vaccinate any adult.  Some local health departments may choose to begin Phase 2B by prioritizing according to age within the phase (for example, by starting off with only those persons 40 years of age and older).  The federal pharmacy program is expanding from approximately 17,000 pharmacies nationwide to about 40,000 pharmacies.  The program is significantly increasing the amount of vaccines available.  Check with your local pharmacy to see if it’s part of the federal program as another option to get vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210401011043/https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-signs-bills-support-military-families-protect-seniors-financial-fraud

name: New Hampshire
notes_C1: As of 22 March 2021, New Hampshire schools have been opened to offer at least two days of in-person learning since 8 March 2021, as mandated by executive order of the Governor. Schools may shut down to do full distance learning for up to 48 hours (without government approval) if there are COVID-19 challenges. Otherwise, full distance learning for longer than 48 hours requires approval. Some NH schools have shut down again because of staff sickness and staffing shortages.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210315013000/https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-85.pdf
notes_C2: As of 22 March 2021, no changes have been identified to workplace restrictions in New Hampshire. Under New Hampshire's 'Stay at Home 2.0' guidelines, employers are encouraged to allow employees or volunteers to work from home as much as practical especially those who are particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 and are at increased risk of severe illness  from COVID-19.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322193642/https://www.covidguidance.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt381/files/files/inline-documents/guidance-universal.pdf
notes_C3: As of 22 March 2021, no evidence has been identified for a change in public event cancellations in New Hampshire. Masks and social distancing are still required at performance venues.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210322191740/https://www.covidguidance.nh.gov/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322192214/https://boston.cbslocal.com/2021/03/12/its-going-to-be-a-very-good-summer-new-hampshire-eases-covid-restrictions-for-travelers-restaurants-and-bars/
notes_C4: As of 22 March 2021, there are no gathering size restrictions.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322193000/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases
notes_C5: As of 22 March 2021, no evidence has been identified for the introduction of new public transportation closures or restrictions in New Hampshire.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322193231/https://www.dot.nh.gov/
notes_C6: Gov Sununu Signs Emergency Order #88, extending Executive Order #52, which advises New Hampshire residents to stay at home in view of the continuing pandemic.    See the Order:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210329183607/https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-88.pdf    See the Emergency Order:
notes_C7: As of 16 March 2021, domestic travel within the U.S. outside of New England no longer requires quarantine upon return to NH, although people are recommended to still follow CDC’s travel guidance, including wearing a well-fitted face mask while traveling, practicing social distancing, getting tested 3-5 days after travel (with a molecular or PCR-based test), and limiting public interactions after travel (even if not required to quarantine).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411161840/https://www.dhhs.nh.gov/dphs/cdcs/covid19/documents/travel-guidance.pdf
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: No evidence has been found to suggest that the winter moratorium on utility disconnections was extended - therefore, this expired on 31 March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411160117/https://www.puc.nh.gov/consumer/winterdisconnectionrules.htm
notes_H1: As of 22 March 2021, New Hampshire's COVID-19 website remains live - this provides information pertaining to the COVID-19 response within the state.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322195346/https://www.nh.gov/covid19/
notes_H2: As of 22 March 2021, no detected change has been found in New Hampshire's testing policy.  Many locations throughout the state offer COVID-19 tests.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322195534/https://www.nh.gov/covid19/resources-guidance/testing-guidance.htm
notes_H3: As of 22 March 2021, there is universal contact tracing.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322195837/https://www.wmur.com/article/covid-19-contact-tracing-resumes-as-state-tracks-new-variants/35772548
notes_H6: Governor Sununu Issues Emergency Order #87, which extends Order #74 - the Mask Mandate requiring masks both indoors and outdoors where social distancing is not possible.     See the extension:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210329181737/https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-87.pdf
notes_H7: New Hampshire expands vaccines to residents 16+ years old. Pfizer, Moderna, J&J. With 150,000 appointments scheduled just that week and additional 42,000 with the expansion of eligibility, capacity seems to be keeping up.    See the announcement:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405184437/https://www.governor.nh.gov/news-and-media/historic-week-new-hampshire-150000-appointments-scheduled

name: New Jersey
notes_C1: The majority of schools are open in some capacity for in-person teaching, unless they cannot meet the state's reopening guidelines.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412204620/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/are-schools-open-what-are-the-safety-requirements
notes_C2: Workplaces must:  Require workers and customers to maintain at least six feet of distance from one another, to the maximum extent possible;  Require everyone to wear face masks, except when an employee is at their workstation at least six feet from others, or is alone in a walled space such as an office - Note: employers may be authorized to prevent individuals who refuse to wear a mask from entering the worksite, where such actions are consistent with state and federal law;  Provide face masks for their employees;  Provide approved sanitization materials for employees and visitors at no cost to those individuals;  Ensure that employees practice hand hygiene and provide employees with sufficient break time for that purpose;  Routinely clean and disinfect all high-touch areas in accordance with DOH and CDC guidelines;  Prior to each shift, conduct daily health checks, such as temperature screenings, visual symptom checking, self-assessment checklists, and/or health questionnaires, consistent with CDC guidance;  Do not allow sick employees to enter workplace and follow requirements of applicable leave laws;  Promptly notify employees of any known exposure to COVID-19 at the worksite;  Clean and disinfect the worksite in accordance with CDC guidelines when an employee at the site has been diagnosed with COVID-19 illness.  Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412204827/https://covid19.nj.gov/pages/safetystandards
notes_C3: Large sports/entertainment venues with capacity for 2500 guests or more are operating indoors at 20% capacity.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412205055/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/how-can-people-safely-get-together-what-are-the-limits-for-indoor-and-outdoor-gatherings
notes_C4: New Jersey is recommending limiting indoor gatherings to immediate family given the recent surges in COVID cases in New York and New Jersey, but general indoor gatherings must be limited to 25 people. All attendees at indoor gatherings must wear face coverings and stay six feet apart.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412205055/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/how-can-people-safely-get-together-what-are-the-limits-for-indoor-and-outdoor-gatherings
notes_C5: New Jersey is operating full light rail and weekday bus operation, with cleaning regimes in place.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412210122/https://www.njtransit.com/covid19
notes_C6: New Jersey recommends unvaccinated residents not to engage in nonessential interstate travel at this time.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412205940/https://nj.gov/governor/news/news/562021/approved/20210405b.shtml
notes_C7: According to the NJ government website, "Unvaccinated travelers and residents returning from any U.S. state or territory beyond the immediate region (New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, and Delaware) should self-quarantine at their home, hotel, or other temporary lodging following recommendations from the CDC:    If travel is unavoidable, travelers should consider getting tested with a viral test (not an antibody test) 1-3 days before the trip and again 3-5 days after the trip." Additionally, "You no longer need to quarantine or get tested before/after domestic travel if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past three months."    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412205547/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/travel-and-transportation/are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: Federal support exists.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412211102/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/assistance-and-benefits/what-types-of-benefits-or-assistance-are-available-to-me-during-the-coronavirus-outbreak
notes_E2: The NJ governor recently announced new measures to protect tenants from illegal lockouts during the evictions moratorium in New Jersey (executive order 106).    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412211316/https://www.nj.com/coronavirus/2021/04/nj-announces-new-measures-to-protect-tenants-from-illegal-lockouts-during-eviction-moratorium.html
notes_H1: Comprehensive public information and vaccine education sites available.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412210248/https://www.nj.gov/health/
notes_H2: Comprehensive testing regime in place.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412210443/https://covid19.nj.gov/pages/testing
notes_H3: Comprehensive contact tracing system in place.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412210517/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/slowing-the-spread/what-is-contact-tracing-how-does-it-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19
notes_H6: New Jersey requires the wearing of face coverings in all public spaces where social distancing is not possible.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412210637/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/slowing-the-spread/should-i-wear-a-mask-to-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19
notes_H7: All adults 16 and up will be eligible for a vaccination starting April 19th.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412210746/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/slowing-the-spread/who-is-eligible-for-vaccination-in-new-jersey-who-is-included-in-the-vaccination-phases

notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7." notes_E2: Eviction moratorium extended through June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402205145/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/ban-renter-evictions-covid-19-pandemic-extended-76747843
notes_H1: Public campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408075352/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/

notes_H6: Regardless of case level, all parts of the state require mask-wearing in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408075352/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/
notes_H7: No policy change. A,B,C:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411005919/https://cv.nmhealth.org/covid-vaccine/

name: Nevada
notes_C1: As of April 6th, Clark County School District, the largest in the state, is operating in a hybrid virtual/in person format for all grades. There is evidence that the 3 largest school districts, CCSD, Washoe County School District, and Elko County School District, are operating in person classes for all groups.     Source (CCSD): https://web.archive.org/web/20210328232528/https://newsroom.ccsd.net/superintendent-announces-school-opening-plan/    Source (Elko): https://archive.vn/ccFgB    Source (Washoe): https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.washoeschools.net/site/handlers/filedownload.ashx?moduleinstanceid=36479&dataid=45247&FileName=2020%20District%20Reopening%20Plan%2010-15%20FINAL%20EN%20web.pdf
notes_C2: As of March 28th, the previous note still holds (replicated below).    "State requirements for closure of certain work sectors, including nightclubs, adult entertainment establishments, brothels, and karaoke businesses, remain in place until controls transition to local authority on May 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301025613/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/NV-Roadmap-to-Recovery-Feb-2021-1.pdf (page 17)"
notes_C3: On March 15th, State Directive 41 went into effect, which allows public events of more than 250 (but less than 50% building capacity) to go ahead if plans are submitted and approved by the state. Public events less than 250 people are allowed, no approval necessary.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Updated-Roadmap-to-Recovery-Master-Guidance-3-12-21.pdf
notes_C4: As of March 28th, the order restricting private gatherings to 10 indoors and 25 outdoors remains.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210327141643/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Updated-Roadmap-to-Recovery-Master-Guidance-3-12-21.pdf (page 5)
notes_C5: As of March 28th, there are no restrictions on public transit in Nevada.
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: On March 31, Directive 43 went into force, which extends the statewide eviction moratorium until the end of May.     Source: https://archive.vn/8Hpke    (original link: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/3.31-Evictions-directive-signed.pdf)
notes_H1: Statewide coordinated public campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315134316/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/current-status-mitigation-measures/
notes_H2: Broad testing policy remains in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308153350/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/find-covid-19-testing-in-nevada/
notes_H3: As of March 28th, it is clear that some contact tracing is being done (including by use of a tracing app) but there is no evidence that it is comprehensive. Although there is little reporting on contact tracing, a news article from February 17th described Southern Nevada's contact tracing as a "miserable failure" with backlogs of up to 25,000 individuals.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210328234143/https://www.8newsnow.com/i-team/i-team-employees-say-snhd-contact-tracing-program-a-miserable-failure/    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210214141637/https://covid.southernnevadahealthdistrict.org/facts/contact-tracing-helps-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19/
notes_H6: As of March 28th, Directive 024, which requires wearing of masks in all public spaces, is still in force.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322094727/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/NV-Roadmap-to-Recovery-Feb-2021-1.pdf    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210321192058/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Directive-024-Face-Coverings.pdf
notes_H7: On April 5th, the vaccine was made available to all individuals 16 and older in Nevada.     Source: https://archive.vn/cYLHx (original link: https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/clark-county/covid-vaccine-appointments-are-open-for-nevadans-16-and-up-2320827/)

name: New York
notes_C1: Starting Monday 12 April, schools "will only be required to switch fully remote for 10 days if it has four or more cases in multiple classrooms and the exposure is traced to the school. After those 10 days and no new outbreaks, students can return to class," according to NBC New York.     Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412200600/https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/coronavirus/nyc-to-debut-new-covid-school-closure-policy-as-rise-of-variants-stoke-anxiety/2987576/
notes_C2: Some workplace closing recommendations still in place.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210329195642/https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-businesses-and-facilities.page
notes_C3: Starting April 2, events, arts, and entertainment venues could reopen at 33% capacity.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412201352/https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-event-arts-and-entertainment-venues-can-reopen-33-percent-capacity
notes_C4: As of March 22, 2021, social gatherings in public spaces, previously limited to 50 people, will be limited to 100 people indoors and 200 people outdoors.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412200928/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/large-gatherings-and-quarantines
notes_C5: NYC public transport is running on a regular schedule, but disinfecting measures are in place.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210405150455/https://new.mta.info/coronavirus
notes_C6: General public info campaign in effect, but no outright stay at home recommendation observed except for symptomatic individuals.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412202541/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/protect-yourself-and-your-family-coronavirus-covid-19
notes_C7: The rules for interstate travel from a non-contiguous state to New York are as follows, according to the government website: "All travelers entering New York from a state that is not a contiguous state who have been outside of New York for more than 24 hours must:    Complete the Traveler Health Form.  Obtain a COVID-19 test within three days of departure, prior to arrival in New York.  Upon arrival in New York, quarantine for three days.    Obtain another COVID-19 test on day 4 of their quarantine,.  If both tests comes back negative, the traveler may exit quarantine early upon receipt of the second negative diagnostic test. Travelers who do not obtain a test prior to arrival in New York and/or on the 4th day in New York, must quarantine for 10 days."    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210329192142/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: New Yorkers can apply for unemployment insurance.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412203814/https://access.nyc.gov/coronavirus-covid-19-updates/
notes_E2: New Yorkers can apply for suspension of debt collection activity due to COVID, and the order is in effect until 30 April 2021.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412203615/https://ag.ny.gov/covid-19-debt-suspension-application
notes_H1: Mask Up America campaign in effect.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412202541/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/protect-yourself-and-your-family-coronavirus-covid-19
notes_H2: Widely available testing.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412202729/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-testing
notes_H3: Comprehensive contact tracing in place.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412202729/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-testing
notes_H6: "New York State (NYS) law requires everyone over age 2 who can medically tolerate a face covering to wear one when in public if unable to maintain at least 6 feet of distance from others"    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412203256/https://www1.nyc.gov/assets/doh/downloads/pdf/imm/covid-19-face-covering-faq.pdf
notes_H7: All New Yorkers ages 16 and up are now eligible for the vaccine.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210412203938/https://covid19vaccine.health.ny.gov/

notes_H3: News report describes contact tracing in Richland County (north central Ohio, population: ~120,000): Richland County continues contact tracing, but much of the efforts are now focused on contact tracing people in the same household (including children) and "contact tracing by proxy", where "staff members ask people who tested positive to contact those they have had close contact but do not live with". name: Oklahoma
notes_C1: As of April 5, 2021, OKCPS are still using their existing A/B hybrid system for students pK-12th. Tulsa public schools continue their hybrid system of in person learning on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays. Tulsa Virtual Academy students  remain in distance learning for the remainder of the year.    OU: No indication of further university closures. Specific university operational restrictions remain the same, where all dining services remain take- away only and the fitness center is open with limited capacity (one in, one out).     Tulsa Board of Education Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230755/https://www.tulsaschools.org/about/news/news-item/~board/district-news/post/board-approves-schedule-for-student-return-to-in-person-learning     Oklahoma City Schools Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230837/https://www.okcps.org/domain/1846     OU Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405230939/https://www.ou.edu/studentaffairs/operations-updates
notes_C2: As of April 5, 2021, certain businesses and workplaces remain closed, with others able to reopen on a gradual basis (Follow link below). On May 1, rodeos and racetracks, full-service restaurants and bars, and museums may reopen with the appropriate social distancing and sanitation guidelines in place.     Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231040/https://www.okcommerce.gov/covid19/open-up-recover-safely-ours-plan-faqs/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210322200611/https://www.governor.ok.gov/articles/press_releases/governor-stitt-signs-new-executive-order-to-contin
notes_C3: As of April 5, 2021,  according to Governor Kevin Stitt’s new guidance (launched March 12, 2021), there are no limits on social or public gatherings. However there have been no evident changes to recommendations on large public events, which is why coding remains 1G.    For some reason no official executive order can be found on the state website.    Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231132/https://www.oklahoman.com/story/news/2021/03/11/oklahoma-gov-kevin-stitt-undo-remaining-covid-19-restrictions/6947773002/
notes_C4: As of April 5, 2021, according to Governor Kevin Stitt’s new guidance (launched March 12, 2021) , there is no limitation  to public gatherings or events.    For some reason no official executive order can be found on the state website.    Link     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231132/https://www.oklahoman.com/story/news/2021/03/11/oklahoma-gov-kevin-stitt-undo-remaining-covid-19-restrictions/6947773002/
notes_C5: As of April 5, 2021, face masks for passengers are still required to be worn properly on Tulsa Transit. Other precautions are taken as advised by the CDC.    Link:   https://archive.vn/HS45N
notes_C6: As of April 5, 2021, most recent reports show that while some counties remain in the yellow phase, some have reverted back to a green status (7 counties). Ways to mitigate spread include limiting out-of-state travel and staying home if feeling sick. General guidelines for high-risk individuals include limiting travel to essential travel only.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231440/https://oklahoma.gov/content/dam/ok/en/covid19/documents/alert-system/risk-level-trends/County%20Risk%20Levels%2020210330.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231510/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/covid-19-alert-system.html
notes_C7: As of April 5, 2021, code remains as 1G recommending restrictions to inter-state travel, especially among higher-risk groups. With the “Safer in Oklahoma” policy, individuals entering the State of Oklahoma from an area with substantial community spread, will wear a face covering in all public spaces and limit participating indoor gatherings for 10-14 days in accordance with CDC guidelines. Public health officials recommend older adults and those with chronic health conditions consider postponing travel.     Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231609/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/resources-recommendations/travel.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: The extension of the moratorium on residential evictions was announced Jan. 20 by the new director of the U.S. Center for Disease Control, Dr. Rochelle Walensky. It now stretches through March 31 and, like earlier iterations, still applies to tenants who make under $99,000.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125171233/https://www.nola.com/news/coronavirus/article_ed5f2886-5d0f-11eb-ba15-6b8247d6c2d7.html
notes_H1: As of April 5, 2021, Oklahoma Department of Health continues to update residents about information regarding the COVID-19 vaccines and encourages them to make appointments to get vaccinated.     Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231736/https://twitter.com/HealthyOklahoma/
notes_H2: As of April 5, 2021, testing remains widely available in Oklahoma with drive through testing available at locations in the Tulsa and Oklahoma City metro areas available for all ages (young children must be able to remain in their seat during the test) and a physician’s referral will not be needed.     Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405231827/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/testing-sites.html     Oklahoma City testing:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322201810/https://www.occhd.org/okctestsites
notes_H3: As of April 5, 2021, Oklahoma tracing remains limited with just about 700 contact tracers working. Participation in contact tracing efforts remains optional.    Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232023/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/resources-recommendations/contact-tracing-0.html     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232204/https://testandtrace.com/state-data/
notes_H6: As of April 5, 2021, code remains as 3T due to the more stringent face covering policy issued by Oklahoma City and Tulsa. The Oklahoma City Council Mask Mandate and the Tulsa mandate is in effect until at least April 30th, 2021.     On a state level, according to Governor Stitt’s order (launched March 12,2021), masks are no longer required in state buildings or properties.  For some reason no official executive order can be found on state website.      Links:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232253/https://kfor.com/news/coronavirus/oklahoma-city-council-defers-vote-on-mask-mandate/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232411/https://www.cityoftulsa.org/covid-19     https://web.archive.org/web/20210308233800/https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/Executive/1984.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232447/https://www.businessinsider.com/oklahoma-governor-lifts-covid-19-restrictions-events-masks-2021-3
notes_H7: On March 29, 2021, Oklahoma moved to Phase 4 in the state's vaccine distribution plan meaning individuals 16+ are now eligible to receive the COVID vaccine.  This means all adults are eligible to receive the COVID vaccine.    Pfizer is authorized for use on individuals 16+, moderna is authorized for use on individuals 18+. Johnson and Johnson is also now being used for individuals 18+.    Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232600/https://vaccinate.oklahoma.gov/en-US/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232634/https://kfor.com/news/local/the-wait-is-over-oklahoma-enters-phase-4-of-covid-19-vaccine-plan/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232734/https://www.governor.ok.gov/articles/press_releases/gov--stitt-receives-johnson---johnson-vaccine-as-o

name: Oregon
notes_C1: Executive order 21-06, issued by the Governor of Oregon, remains in place. The order requires all schools K-12 to move to either hybrid-model learning or on-site learning no later than the week of March 29 for grades K-5 and no later than April 19 for grades 6-12. COVID-19 safety protocols (masking, physical distancing, and testing/isolation) are still required on-site.    https://archive.fo/4YsGx
notes_C2: 14 counties are ranked at 'high' risk level, 6 at 'moderate' and 16 at 'lower'. At the current highest risk level, remote work is encouraged, indoor dining is allowed though takeout is highly recommended. Indoor capacity: not to exceed 25% maximum occupancy or 50 people, whichever is smaller. At the lowest risk level, indoor dining allowed, capacity not to exceed 50% maximum occupancy, limited office work is allowed, and retails stores are allowed at 75% max capacity.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210409162346/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/living-with-covid-19.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406233549/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/guidance.aspx
notes_C3: 14 counties are ranked at 'high' risk level, 6 at 'moderate' and 16 at 'lower'. At the lowest level, Maximum 12 people are allowed to gather outside, and outdoor entertainment venues may have maximum 50% occupancy and 12 a.m. closing time.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210409162346/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/living-with-covid-19.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406233549/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/guidance.aspx
notes_C4: 14 counties are ranked at 'high' risk level, 6 at 'moderate' and 16 at 'lower'.  At the lowest risk level, maximum 10 people may gather indoors. Recommended limit: 4 households      https://web.archive.org/web/20210409162346/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/living-with-covid-19.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406233549/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/guidance.aspx
notes_C5: No evidence of public transportation closing in Oregon as a result of or in response to Covid-19.
notes_C6: Guidance in Oregon indicates that residence should stay home if sick.     https://archive.vn/l0geC
notes_C7: The following order remains in effect:    Individuals arriving in Oregon from other states or countries for non-essential travel,  including returning Oregon residents, should, but are not required to:  • Self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival;  • Limit their interactions to their immediate household   While a 14-day quarantine is the safest option to prevent the spread of COVID-19 to others,  those who have traveled to Oregon or back home to Oregon may consider ending quarantine  early1  if they have not had any symptoms:  • After 10 days, without any testing  OR  • After 7 days, if they receive a negative test result from an antigen or polymerase chain  reaction (PCR) test that was conducted within 48 hours of the end of the 7-day period.     https://archive.vn/IiTMm
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: The following policy remains in effect:  PUA provides unemployment benefits to workers who have never before been eligible for benefits. To qualify, you must be:  Out of work due to COVID-19, and  Not eligible for any other unemployment benefits. This includes:  Self-employed people  Independent contractors  Some gig workers (gig workers whose employers are not required to pay payroll taxes on their wages)  Employees whose wages are not reported for unemployment insurance, like some agricultural workers  Employees who have not earned enough wages or worked enough hours for regular unemployment benefits  Employees who ran out of regular unemployment benefits, and are not eligible for another extension  People who were going to start work but could not, due to a COVID-19 situation  The minimum PUA benefit is $205 per week. You will get at least that much if you are eligible. The maximum is $648 per week. Your weekly benefit amount is 1.25 percent of your earnings over the last 12 months. It is net earnings (earnings minus expenses) for self-employed workers, but gross earnings (total earnings) for other workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331213858/https://unemployment.oregon.gov/frequently-asked-questions#faqTopic-2008
notes_E2: Oregon's moratorium on residential evictions continues through June 30, 2021 (House Bill 4401). The statewide eviction moratorium makes it unlawful for landlords to evict people who are unable to pay their rent and for landlords to evict renters without cause.     The Oregon Public Utility Commission's stipulated agreements made in November with utility providers, state, in general, that utilities will not be shut off due to non-payment.     Moratorium on evictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20210215175536/https://secureservercdn.net/45.40.144.200/92j.af1.myftpupload.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/2021-Eviction-moratorium-OLC-LASO3.pdf    PUC: https://web.archive.org/web/20210215180110/https://www.oregon.gov/puc/Pages/Consumer-Information-Center.aspx
notes_H1: Oregon's public health campaign includes a website for public use on Covid-19 resources:     https://archive.vn/Laopg
notes_H2: The following policy for testing remains in place:  1. Testing is available to those who are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19, such as fever, cough, or shortness of breath  2. Each coronavirus test provider will determine if testing is appropriate based on symptoms, risk factors, and test availability.  3. Due to an increase in demand, there may be longer than usual wait times for testing and results in certain areas.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210328182202/https://govstatus.egov.com/or-oha-covid-19-testing
notes_H3: Oregon conducts contact tracing, however the current contact rates are not meeting state-set targets. In the week of March 21, 87% of cases were contacted by health officials, which falls short of the target of 95%.    https://archive.vn/PlglF
notes_H6: Masks are currently required statewide at all times unless you are:    At your own residence.  In your own personal vehicle.  Under five (5) years of age.  Eating or drinking.  Engaged in an activity that makes wearing a mask, face covering or face shield not feasible, such as when taking a shower.  Sleeping.  In a private, individual workspace.  Removing the mask briefly because your identity needs to be confirmed by visual comparison, such as at a bank or if interacting with law enforcement.    https://archive.fo/sXFWu
notes_H7: Governor announced that vaccine eligibility will be expanded to include everyone over the age of 16, starting on April 19. Until then, the previous vaccine policy remains in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406175637/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54465

name: Pennsylvania
notes_C1: "For Phase II, students in grades 3 through 5 and students with complex needs in grades 6-8 whose families select the hybrid learning model would transition to a mix of in-person and digital learning each week, based on their assigned schedule, beginning Monday, April 26th.  All staff supporting grades 3 through 8 will return to school buildings on Monday, April 12th." notes_C4: Some changes in occupancy, but no change in code. See below for new guidelines:    "Child care safety guidance in place  Congregate care restrictions in place  Prison and hospital restrictions determined by individual facilities  Schools subject to CDC and commonwealth guidance  Telework is strongly encouraged  Businesses with in-person operations must follow updated business and building safety requirements  Face coverings are required in businesses  All in-person businesses may operate at 75% occupancy  Indoor dining at restaurants open at 50% (75% for self-certified restaurants)"    "Gathering limits in place:  Indoor events: 25% of maximum occupancy, regardless of venue size and only if attendees and workers are able to comply with the 6-foot physical distancing requirement  Outdoor events: 50% of maximum occupancy, regardless of venue size and only if attendees and workers are able to comply with the 6-foot physical distancing requirement  Face coverings are required to be worn indoors and outdoors if you are away from your home"    Sources:  https://archive.vn/HeXVo    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404192355/https://6abc.com/pennsylvania-restaurant-bar-service-permitted-pa-covid-19-restrictions-gov-tom-wolf-restaurants/10483306/
notes_C5: No change.    "General Announcement:  All SEPTA passengers are required to wear a face mask or covering. Regular service schedules are in effect. The 12th & Filbert doors at Jefferson Station are open 7 days a week from 6:30 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. The 16th & JFK doors at Suburban Station will be open during the following hours: 6:30 a.m. to 9:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. (Monday-Friday only). During all other hours these doors will be locked. We appreciate your patience during this time.  Bus:  Routes 128, 130, 14, 58, BLVDDIR : Service will not operate to the stop inside the Neshaminy Mall complex when the mall is closed from the hours of 8 p.m. until 10 a.m. starting Wed., April 7. Details on stop locations during these hours are available online.  Trolley:  Routes 10, 11, 13, 36 : The trolley tunnel is closed overnight seven days a week from 12 a.m. to 5 a.m. due to an ongoing COVID-19 enhanced maintenance and station deep cleaning program.  Regional Rail:  Chestnut Hill East : Please board all trains on the outbound platform from 7:00 am to 5:00 pm Saturday and Sunday due to tree removal operations.  Cynwyd : Service is suspended until further notice.  Norristown High Speed Line:  Norristown High Speed Line : All trains will board from the outbound platforms between Hughes Park and Radnor Stations on Sunday, April 11 from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. Parkview and County Line Stations will remain open for service.  CCT:  CCT : Full service is operating. Vehicles will limit the number of customers per vehicle to comply with social distancing guidelines. Please have exact fare ready to minimize contact with drivers. All customers are reminded to wear masks/face coverings while on board."    Source:  https://archive.vn/zUdPA
notes_C6: No change.    PA Dept of Health's Twitter page continues recommending individuals to stay at home until everyone can get vaccinated.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327203654/https://twitter.com/PAHealthDept/status/1341398094684930048
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: No change on unemployment benefits websites.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403223624/https://www.uc.pa.gov/unemployment-benefits/file/Pages/Filing-for-PUA.aspx    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411181143/https://www.uc.pa.gov/COVID-19/Pages/default.aspx
notes_E2: No change in code. Moratoriums on evictions and foreclosures are federal.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403224219/https://www.uwp.org/pacovid/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403224727/https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/wolf-administration-partners-with-general-assembly-pennsylvania-counties-to-launch-the-emergency-rental-assistance-program/
notes_H1: No change. Campaigns appear up to date.    Source:  https://archive.vn/HeXVo
notes_H2: No change.    "No appointment is necessary. Testing is on a first-come, first-serve basis and is completely free to all patients. Patients must be ages three and older and are not required to show symptoms of COVID-19 in order to be tested. Up to 450 patients can be tested per day. Mid-nasal passage swab PCR tests will be performed. Patients are encouraged to bring a photo-ID or insurance card. Registration will also be completed on-site. The turnaround time for testing results is two to seven days after testing."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411194157/https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Public%20Testing.aspx
notes_H3: No change.    "If you test positive, a public health staff member will try to call you within 24 to 48 hours of receiving the test result. They will conduct a case investigation or share a Connect & Protect Form and collect the people and places you come in contact with while you were infectious. While you isolate for a minimum of ten days, contact tracers will reach out to your close contacts to inform them that they were exposed, educate them on what to do and provide supports and testing information as necessary for the situation. Contact tracers will not use your name when reaching out to your close contacts. Your information will stay confidential."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411194311/https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Contact-Tracing.aspx
notes_H6: No change.    "The Order requires individuals to wear a face covering when indoors, irrespective of physical distance. When outdoors, one must wear a face covering when with others who are not members of the person's household and unable to maintain sustained physical distance."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411195359/https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Guidance/Universal-Masking-FAQ.aspx
notes_H7: A,B,C: A- Key workers, B- Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), C- Elderly groups    Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are being administered.    PA moves into Phase 1B of its vaccination plan. Philadelphia (a separate vaccination jurisdiction) begins Phase 1C of its vaccination plan.    PA:  "Starting today, Pennsylvanians in Phase 1B of the state’s vaccination plan are now eligible to schedule a COVID-19 vaccination appointment to become protected against the virus. Phase 1B eligible Pennsylvanians include:    People in congregate settings not otherwise specified as long-term care facilities, and persons receiving home and community-based services  U.S. Postal Service workers  Manufacturing workers  Clergy and other essential support for houses of worship  Public transit workers  Education workers"    New eligible groups in Philadelphia in Phase 1C:  "Sanitation workers  Maintenance and janitorial staff  Utility workers  Postal and package delivery workers"    Sources:  https://archive.vn/xCbYF  https://archive.vn/b9vB5  https://archive.fo/aN7w2

name: Rhode Island
notes_C1: As of 15 March 2021, schools in Rhode Island are open for in-person or blended learning. Face coverings are required for all staff and K-12 students, at all times, even in stable group settings, and even when socially distanced.    No evidence found to suggest that in-person learning does not continue to some extent at University of Rhode Island.    Back2School RI website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315195049/https://www.back2schoolri.com/    RI schools guidance:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315195157/https://www.ride.ri.gov/Portals/0/Uploads/Documents/COVID19/HealthandSafetyReopeningGuidance.pdf?ver=2021-03-10-110839-843    URI latest update:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315201853/https://web.uri.edu/coronavirus/2021/03/12/vaccination-covid-19-updates/
notes_C2: On March 26th, the state of Rhode Island updated its reopening guidance. Governor Daniel J. McKee issued EO 21-29, encouraging outdoor dining but still limiting outdoor seating capacity to 10 people. People should work remotely if possible. This order is effective until April 17th.    Per EO 21-22, nightclubs must be closed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210329045407/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-29.pdf   http://web.archive.org/web/20210329045017/https://reopeningri.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Protect-Your-Household-Guidance.pdf
notes_C3: On March 26th, the state of Rhode Island updated its reopening guidance. There was no substantial change. Gatherings were still limited to 15 people inside and 50 people outside. The number of event attendees is limited to 100 people indoors and 200 people outdoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210329045017/https://reopeningri.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Protect-Your-Household-Guidance.pdf
notes_C4: On March 26th, the state of Rhode Island updated its reopening guidance. There was no substantial change. Gatherings were still limited to 15 people inside and 50 people outside. The number of event attendees is limited to 100 people indoors and 200 people outdoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210329045017/https://reopeningri.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Protect-Your-Household-Guidance.pdf
notes_C5: As of 14 March 2021, no evidence has been found for amendments to public transportation services in Rhode Island.     Rhode Island Public Transit Authority states that face masks are required to be worn at all times and social distancing should be observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314210047/https://www.ripta.com/covid-19/
notes_C6: On March 19th, Governor Daniel J. McKee issued EO 21-27, encouraging vulnerable people to stay at home. This order is effective until April 17th.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210324034558/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf
notes_C7: On March 19th, Governor Daniel J. McKee issued EO 21-27, extending domestic and international travel restrictions. People who have travelled outside Rhode Island and the US must self-quarantine for 10 days. Exemptions apply. This order is effective until April 17th.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210324034558/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: As of 14 March 2021, those who have been laid off due to the pandemic may be eligible for the state's unemployment insurance. If individuals are self-employed or a contract worker, they must apply for Pandemic Unemployment Assistance.    It is unclear whether this support provides <50% or >50% of the lost income. Coding as 1F, however this may not reflect the situation on the ground.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314202859/https://dlt.ri.gov/ui/faq/
notes_E2: On March 19th, winter moratorium on utilities was extended until June 25, 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210405095646/https://www.providenceri.gov/pema/covid-19-housing-resource-guide/
notes_H1: As of 14 March 2021, Rhode Island's Department of Health continues to provide information pertaining to the COVID-19 response within the state via the RIDOH COVID-19 website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314195805/https://covid.ri.gov/
notes_H2: As of 14 March 2021, there is no detected change in Rhode Island's testing policy.    Testing is currently widely available for those who are both symptomatic and asymptomatic.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210314200512/https://covid.ri.gov/testing
notes_H3: As of 14 March 2021, no evidence has been identified to suggest a deviation away from comprehensive contact tracing in Rhode Island.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314200137/https://covid.ri.gov/covid-19-prevention/contact-tracing
notes_H6: As of 14 March 2021, EO 20-30 remains in effect. Face masks are still required to be worn are still required in all public spaces, whether indoors or outdoors, unless a mask exception applies.     RIDOH website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314195805/https://covid.ri.gov/    EO 20-30:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314195830/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-30.pdf
notes_H7: A, B, C: Starting March 31st, Rhode Island Department of Health allowed people from hard-hit communities—certain zip codes in Central Falls, Pawtucket, and Providence—to be vaccinated.
