notes_H1: Ongoing public health campaign    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411230212/https://scdhec.gov/
notes_H2: "Who should get tested?  Anyone who would like to be tested.  If you are out and about in the community, we recommend that you receive routine testing once a month or sooner if someone you’ve been around tests positive or if you develop symptoms.     In addition, DHEC recommends routine testing of individuals with known exposures or concerns about exposures. Routine testing allows public health workers to diagnose those who are asymptomatic and interrupt the ongoing spread of the virus."    Retrieved from the SC Dept of Health and Environmental Control website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412204519/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/who-should-get-tested-covid-19
notes_H3: "DHEC has been conducting contact tracing for COVID-19 cases since the first reports in the state. Contact tracing includes two components: case investigations and contact monitoring. Currently, DHEC has more than 740 individuals trained to perform case investigations across the state, supplemented by 230 active contact monitors. A total of 600 contact monitors have been trained to date and will be deployed as needed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412204814/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-contact-tracing
notes_H6: Mask ordinances in 9 counties.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210412205157/https://scemd.maps.arcgis.com/sharing/rest/oauth2/authorize?client_id=arcgisonline&display=default&response_type=token&state=%7B%22returnUrl%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fscemd.maps.arcgis.com%2Fapps%2Fopsdashboard%2Findex.html%22%2C%22useLandingPage%22%3Afalse%7D&expiration=20160&locale=en-us&redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fscemd.maps.arcgis.com%2Fhome%2Faccountswitcher-callback.html&force_login=false&hideCancel=true&showSignupOption=true&canHandleCrossOrgSignIn=true&signuptype=esri&redirectToUserOrgUrl=true
notes_H7: "Currently, all South Carolinians age 16 and older can get their COVID-19 vaccine.    South Carolina's phased approach to its COVID-19 vaccine rollout was focused on saving lives, which is why those most at risk for severe illness and death were prioritized to receive vaccine first. With more and more vaccine becoming available and more and more people receiving their shots, South Carolina is now able to open vaccines to anyone 16 and older."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412205826/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-vaccine

name: South Dakota
notes_C1: K-12 schools in Sioux Falls and Rapid City (South Dakota's largest cities) are operating normally with  COVID-19 precaution measures and building/procedure modification in place, therefore the code remains at 1G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411235705/https://rcas.org/status/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411235815/https://www.smore.com/9dh4z
notes_C2: As of April 6th, there have been no policy changes. The CDC does not mandate or recommend closing any specific sector, but it does provide guidelines on Covid mitigation in various sectors. The CDC defers to local authorities for closures or restrictions.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214901/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405232540/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: As of April 6th, the CDC recommends against large gatherings. Guidelines are provided for exposure mitigation in congregate settings.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: No further updates on gathering restrictions.     Link to most recent executive order effective on Jan 7,2021:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210209000239/https://sdsos.gov/general-information/executive-actions/executive-orders/assets/2021-01.PDF
notes_C5: South Dakota Department of Transport website shows no indication of public transport closures due to COVID-19 Link: https://archive.fo/6bQfL
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: The South Dakota Housing Development Authority provides emergency housing and utility assistance for South Dakota residents through Federal COVID Stimulus funds. "If you have been financially impacted due to COVID-19, the SD CARES Housing Assistance Program may provide temporary housing and/or utility assistance for South Dakota residents who meet all of the following criteria..." As of Apr 5, the application on this site continues to be accessible.
notes_H1: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) continues its coordinated public information campaign.     CDC COVID-19 website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329173924/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/index.html    CDC Novel Coronavirus Reports webpage (includes the MMWR COVID-19 Weekly Briefing podcast, a "brief weekly podcast series to highlight the latest scientific information from the COVID-19 response"):   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329173936/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/Novel_Coronavirus_Reports.html    CDC Twitter:  https://archive.vn/iSBiH
notes_H2: South Dakota Health of Department continues to provide free COVID-19 testing, including at home kits    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405045447/https://learn.vaulthealth.com/southdakota/
notes_H3: There is a voluntary app called Care19 Diary App that can be downloaded in South Dakota that tracks your location via bluetooth. It is not clear how many people use the app.     Note: South Dakota Department of Health website cannot be reached by users with an EU IPP for further information.    Link to app information: https://archive.fo/p0psW
notes_H6: The cities of Huron and Brookings (in effect until 30 April) still have mask mandates in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405044144/https://www.huronsd.com/assets/file-manager/City-Government/covid-19/resolution-2021-02-covid.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405044244/https://www.cityofbrookings-sd.gov/699/Guidelines-Ordinance-Information
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson's    Starting April 5th, South Dakota opens Phase 2 (ages 16 and older) COVID-19 vaccine eligibility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411233421/https://ktiv.com/2021/04/05/south-dakota-governor-gets-covid-19-vaccine-marks-opening-of-vaccine-eligibility/

name: Tennessee
notes_C1: As of March 29, a large number of schools in Tennessee have returned to in person learning. The states two largest districts Metro Nashville Public Schools (MNPS) and Shelby County Schools (SCS) returned using phased in approaches. MNPS returned to in-person learning in early February while still allowing parents to opt for remote learning and SCS began bringing students back for person learning on March 5.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329233952/https://www.mnps.org/blog/2021/1/29/returning-to-school-buildings-an-update?rq=covid
notes_C2: As of March 29, a large number of businesses have reopened in the state. For example, Nashville is in phase 3 of its reopening plan with businesses such as bars and restaurants reopened, but with restrictions on capacity, closing times and safety measures in place.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330000247/https://www.asafenashville.org/roadmap-for-reopening-nashville-phase-3-guidance-and-resources/
notes_C3: As of March 29, there are some restrictions in place regarding public events. Events can have up to 1,000 attendees if approved by the city. April 28 will see Nashville move into the next phase of reopening where 2,000 people will be allowed to gather at low risk outdoor events with Health Department approval.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330000247/https://www.asafenashville.org/roadmap-for-reopening-nashville-phase-3-guidance-and-resources/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330002415/https://fox17.com/news/local/nashville-relaxes-covid-19-restrictions-on-bars-restaurants-gatherings-and-more-business-economy-mandates-vaccines
notes_C4: As of March 29, some restrictions on gatherings remain in place. For example in Nashville, gatherings must be limited to 8 people or fewer currently. Community gatherings such as block parties, backyard events, house parties, etc. must remain limited to small groups of 8 or fewer at this time. The stage of reopening in Nashville on April 28 will see this increase to 10 people indoors.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330000247/https://www.asafenashville.org/roadmap-for-reopening-nashville-phase-3-guidance-and-resources/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330002856/https://www.huschblackwell.com/tennessee-state-by-state-covid-19-guidance#:~:text=Indoor%20gathering%20limits%20will%20increases,floor%20(with%20social%20distancing).
notes_C5: 15 March: Nashville's WeGo Transit service still offers a reduced service due to COVID-19.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315232445/https://www.asafenashville.org/status-of-nashville-services/
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: There appear to be a limited number of programs on offer for assistance with rent, utility and other payments. The Tennessee State Courts have compiled a list of agency-wide benefits, available here: http://web.archive.org/web/20210202001852/https://www.tncourts.gov/Eviction%20Resources.  It is unclear how long these programs have been going, but evidence suggests they have been intermittent since at least 1 December 2020.
notes_H1: 15 March: Tennessee continues to run a campaign coordinated across social media and traditional media. Consider, for example, the Tennessee Strong Mask Movement—this is a government-led public awareness campaign to encourage the use of face masks. The Movement involves corporate partners, video messages and social media posts.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315232852/https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/economic-recovery/mask-movement.html
notes_H2: 15 March: Testing remains generally available in Tennessee. Several of the testing sites listed on the website do not require pre-booking or symptom screening.     Here are the sites as of 15 March: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315233127/https://covid19.tn.gov/testing-sites/
notes_H3: 15 March: The "General Guidelines" on the state website mention "notifying close contacts" and "contact tracing", but actual reports on the process itself are sparse on the government website. Thus, there is no indication that Tennessee has moved from limited to comprehensive contact tracing.     Read the general guidelines here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315232706/https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/economic-recovery/general-guidelines-for-businesses.html
notes_H6: 22 March: Nashville, and other cities, still require face masks where social distancing is not possible.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322202207/https://www.asafenashville.org/roadmap-for-reopening-nashville-phase-3-guidance-and-resources/
notes_H7: Per an announcement made by Governor Bill Lee on 22 March, all Tennesseans became eligible for vaccination on 5 April. It is assumed that jabs began going into arms on this date, thus the coding changes to a 5G here.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412204524/https://www.tn.gov/health/news/2021/3/22/all-tennessee-adults-eligible-for-covid-19-vaccination-by-april-5.html

name: Texas
notes_C1: As of April 5, 2021 Texas schools still have freedom to decide whether or not to follow the Texas Education Agency (TEA) released guidelines based on the new executive order GA 34. TEA updated guidelines, now recommend a distance of three feet in schools but encourage 6 feet when possible. Masks should be worn by students, teachers and staff members, whenever it is not possible to maintain 3 feet social distancing. TEA recommends that public school systems consult with their local public health authorities and local legal counsel before making final decisions regarding the implementation of this guidance.    Most Texas school districts remain open, but also offer virtual learning. Many continue to provide daily, on-campus learning for any family who wants it in order to not lose state funding due to declines in enrollment. School districts can require individual students who are falling behind academically to return to in-person classes.    Mostly all Texas Universities have chosen to keep COVID-19 policies in place, even though Governor Abbott ended the mask mandate (MArch 10th, 2021). While some schools continue with complete virtual learning for spring semester, others continue hybrid learning. Texas A&M continues their mandatory testing program for students.    Links:    School Closure Map by State:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405202641/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-where-are-schools-closed/2020/07       Texas Education Agency (TEA) Guidance Link and Press Release Update:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327074522/https://tea.texas.gov/sites/default/files/covid/SY-20-21-Public-Health-Guidance.pdf     Texas University Updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405202728/https://www.tamu.edu/coronavirus/testing-locations/index.html     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405202842/https://www.kxan.com/texas-universities-and-schools-response-to-coronavirus/
notes_C2: As of April 5, 2021, Austin and Travis counties still require at least 6 feet between groups of 10 or fewer and face coverings in establishments and businesses. This is part of the Health Authority Emergency Rules, set to expire April 15, 2021and the most recent executive order, set to expire April 21st, 2021. As a result, coding remains 2T.    For the greater state of Texas, Executive Order GA34 is still in effect.  In all counties without high hospitalization, there are no COVID-19 related operation limits for any business or establishments (e.g., gyms, salons, restaurants, public and private schools, childcare services). Businesses can now operate at 100% occupancy, unless county judges use COVID related mitigation strategies-limited to no less than a 50% total occupancy.       Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis, Texas Guidelines:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203007/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules     https://web.archive.org/web/20210305065233/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Order-No-20210216-026-Final.pdf
notes_C3: As of April 5, 2021, Austin and Travis County still follow the “Stay Home, Mask, and Otherwise Be safe” orders, effective until April 21, 2021. Gatherings or presence at any outdoor area, event or establishment of more than 10 persons are prohibited, with a few exceptions (listed in orders).    For the greater state of Texas, Executive Order GA34 is still in effect. There are no evident executive state orders on the limit or restriction of public events.       Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis County Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203007/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules     https://web.archive.org/web/20210305065233/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Order-No-20210216-026-Final.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210224233055/https://www.traviscountytx.gov/images/docs/200314-gathering-order.pdf
notes_C4: As of April 5, 2021, Austin and Travis County still follow the “Stay Home, Mask, and Otherwise Be safe” orders, effective until April 21, 2021. Social gatherings up to 10 people should be avoided or minimized, and socializing in groups of 10+ individuals outside of the same household is prohibited.    On a state level, Executive Order GA34 remains in effect.  There are no evident executive state orders on the limit or restriction on gatherings. However, individuals are strongly encouraged (not required) to wear face coverings when it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household, based on unvaccinated status.      Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis County Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203007/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules     https://web.archive.org/web/20210305065233/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Order-No-20210216-026-Final.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210224233055/https://www.traviscountytx.gov/images/docs/200314-gathering-order.pdf
notes_C5: No updates on website for Sun Metro (El Paso County's public transportation provider) regarding  changes in bus schedule or closures. Called on 11/11 to confirm this information was accurate.     Link to Sun Metro Website:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201111165513/http://www.sunmetro.net/
notes_C6: As of April 5, 2021, Executive Order GA34 remains in effect.  There are no evident state executive state stay at home orders.    Nevertheless, Austin and Travis County extended the “Stay Home, Mask, and Otherwise Be safe” orders through April 21, 2021.The local health authority continues to encourage people to stay home unless something is necessary. For this reason coding remains 1T.    links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis County Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203007/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules     https://web.archive.org/web/20210305065233/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Order-No-20210216-026-Final.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210224233055/https://www.traviscountytx.gov/images/docs/200314-gathering-order.pdf
notes_C7: As of April 5, 2021, Austin remains stage 3. There is no longer a guideline to avoid non-essential internal travel for people at high risk. Nevertheless, Austin and Travis County extended the “Stay Home, Mask, and Otherwise Be safe” orders through April 21, 2021.    links:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203220/https://www.austintexas.gov/page/covid-19-risk-based-guidelines     Stage Guidelines Link:    https://archive.ph/2Vj18
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: As of April 5, 2021, the Texas Rent Relief Program continues (Launched Feb.15, 2021). The program provides monetary assistance to households in paying rent or utilities, Qualifying households can make no more than 80% of an area’s median income. Priority will be given to households making less than 50% of an areas median income or household members unemployed for at least 90 days.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203321/https://texasrentrelief.com/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210209191920/https://www.statesman.com/story/news/politics/state/2021/02/09/texas-gov-greg-abbott-rent-relief-program-launches-covid-pandemic/4449250001/
notes_E2: As of April 5, 2021 the Texas Eviction Diversion Program remains in effect.       Link to the TEDP:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210402230513/https://www.tdhca.state.tx.us/TEDP.htm     https://web.archive.org/web/20210217203258/https://www.txcourts.gov/media/1451765/219015.pdf
notes_H1: As of April 5, 2021, up to date information on covid is still provided through social media (e.g., twitter) and the Texas government website.    Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203457/https://www.texas.gov/covid19/     https://archive.vn/x3ch2
notes_H2: As of April 5, 2021, public screening and antibody collection sites are still available statewide- in person and at drive through locations. People with symptoms are encouraged to get tested, but symptoms are not required for a test.    General Testing Information Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405204426/https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/testing.aspx     Testing Location Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330081300/https://tdem.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=1e91fb79fa44417898738e5bff31a3d8/
notes_H3: As of April 5, 2021 contact tracing efforts continue in Texas but participation in efforts is voluntary.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405204806/https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/tracing.aspx
notes_H6: As of April 5, 2021, Austin and Travis County still follow the “Stay Home, Mask, and Otherwise Be safe” orders, effective until April 21, 2021. Face coverings in establishments, businesses, and in public areas are required. Austin has clearance to enforce its own mandate, given court ruling (March 26 2021). As a result, coding remains 3T.    On a state level, Executive Order GA34 remains in effect.  All mask mandates have been removed. While individuals are no longer required by law to wear face coverings, individuals are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings when it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household (unvaccinated status).    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis County Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405203007/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules
notes_H7: On March 29, 2021 Texas expanded its vaccine roll out to all people 16+. Vaccine eligibility is now for all the public (age 16+, as no FDA approval has been given to use vaccines on children younger than 16).    Moderna vaccine is being used for individuals 18 and older, while the Pfizer vaccine is authorized for people 16 and older.     Texas State Vaccination Requirement Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405204952/https://dshs.texas.gov/coronavirus/immunize/vaccine.aspx     Texas DSHS/ News Vaccine Update:  https://archive.vn/x3ch2     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405205117/https://www.kvue.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/vaccine/austin-vaccine-public-health-eligibility/269-c69a531c-0c2b-46b6-a3fa-26de55b68fae

name: Utah
notes_C1: General reopening with some restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402210353if_/https://schools.utah.gov/coronavirus?mid=4985&aid=3
notes_C2: As per state guidance, workplaces in areas under high or moderate levels of COVID-19 transmission (no remaining high-transmission counties, many moderate-transmission counties)  are required to enforce the use of face masks and 6ft distancing between parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410165253/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C3: As per state guidance, public events in areas under high or moderate levels of COVID-19 transmission are required to enforce the use of face masks and 6ft distancing between parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410165253/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C4: No longer recommended to limit gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410165253/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C5: There are no measures on closing public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410165253/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C6: No stay-at-home requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410165253/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: Coordinated public information campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410165253/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_H2: Testing available to those who are symptomatic and/or who made effective contact with someone who has COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402211222/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/
notes_H3: Limited contact tracing efforts continue.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402211222/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/
notes_H6: Facial coverings are required by some businesses and public gatherings over 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410165253/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_H7: On March 24th, the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines became universally available to all Utahns 16+. The currently available vaccines have not yet been approved for those younger than 16 years old.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411215338/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/vaccine/

name: Virginia
notes_C1: As of March 30, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C2: As of March 30, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C3: As of April 1, 2021, outdoor entertainment venues will continue to operate at 30% capacity, while indoor entertainment venues can have a maximum of 500 people, which is an increase from 250 people. This policy remains coded as 1G.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401224943/https://www.virginiabusiness.com/article/breaking-va-to-loosen-covid-restrictions-april-1/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401225108/https://www.wavy.com/news/health/coronavirus/some-covid-19-restrictions-in-virginia-rolled-back-starting-today/
notes_C4: As of April 1, 2021, “Social gatherings increase from a limit of 25 people outdoors and 10 people indoors currently to 50 people indoors and 100 people in outdoor settings after April 1” according to the governor’s office. Thus, this policy has been downgraded from 4G to 3G.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401224943/https://www.virginiabusiness.com/article/breaking-va-to-loosen-covid-restrictions-april-1/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401225108/https://www.wavy.com/news/health/coronavirus/some-covid-19-restrictions-in-virginia-rolled-back-starting-today/
notes_C5: As of March 30, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C6: As of March 30, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: As of March 5, 2021, Virginia is still offering rent relief, which is funded through the Rent Relief Program. As an update, these new funds “do not permit mortgages to be paid from” them. This remains coded as 1.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210316210435/https://www.wtvr.com/rebound/rent-relief-program-no-longer-includes-mortgage-payments
notes_H1: As of March 30, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H2: As of March 30, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H3: Contact tracing is handled on a statewide level. Depending on the state, contact tracing is led by the state health department and/or by local health departments. All states appear to have some level of contact tracing. Few states report their contact tracing statistics, so it is difficult to gauge the efficacy of contact tracing.     A CDC report published on 22 January 2021 indicated that "the capacity to conduct timely contact tracing varied among health departments, largely driven by investigators’ caseloads," and suggesting that contact tracing was not comprehensive across the nation.     The number of COVID tests per 100k people may be one proxy for the level of contact tracing (see CDC COVID Data Tracker). Certain states such as Alaska and Massachusetts currently appear to have the highest rate of RT-PCR tests.    Delaware does publish its contact tracing statistics. From 27 June 2020 to 26 March 2021, the health department has only reached 50% of total contacts.    CDC COVID Data Tracker Dashboard:  https://archive.vn/TA0U6    CDC Report on contact tracing (22 January 2021):  https://archive.vn/anXSS    National Academy for State Health Policy (NASHP) State Approaches to Contact Tracing:  https://archive.vn/N4YNh    Delaware Contact Tracing Statistics:  https://archive.vn/GAkYB
notes_H6: As of March 30, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H7: As of April 5, 2021, the following counties in Virginia have entered phase 2 of vaccination, in which all Virginians age 16 and older are able to receive vaccinations: Accomack, Alleghany, Amherst, Appomattox, Bedford, Botetourt, Brunswick, Campbell, Clarke, Craig, Culpeper, Fauquier, Franklin, Frederick, Halifax, Henry, Madison, Mecklenburg, Northampton, Orange, Page, Patrick, Rappahannock, Roanoke, Shenandoah, Warren. The rest of the state is still in phase 1C and is set to enter phase 2 on April 18 according to Governor Northam. Virginia continues to offer Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson&Johnson. This policy remains coded at 3G because parts of the state are still in phase 1C and are only offering vaccines to key workers, the clinically vulnerable, and the elderly.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405205525/https://www.virginiabusiness.com/article/covid-roundup-parts-of-va-open-vaccinations-to-all-over-age-16/

name: Vermont
notes_C1: As of 5 April 2021, no change has been detected. Continuing to code as 2T - neither universities nor schools are completely open for in-person teaching.    University of Vermont is delivering an unknown proportion of its classes in-person.     Schools dashboard:  https://archive.fo/wKdh9    UVM update:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405104221/https://www.uvm.edu/provost/news/important-faculty-updates-april-2-2021
notes_C2: As of 4 April 2021, as laid out in the 'Be Smart, Stay Safe' order, all businesses and non-profit and government entities shall encourage and facilitate telework among those employees with the capacity to work remotely when practical without impeding productivity.    'Be Smart, Stay Safe' Order:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404200509/https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-be-smart-stay-safe-order
notes_C3: As of 4 April 2021, there are currently multiple household gathering restrictions across the state, where unvaccinated households or individuals only allowed to gather with more than one other unvaccinated household or individual, as long as it is just two unvaccinated households or individuals at any one gathering. It is, therefore, assumed that public events are required to be cancelled.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404200509/https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-be-smart-stay-safe-order
notes_C4: As of 2 April 2021, limitations on household gatherings remain in place in Vermont.     - Vaccinated individuals or households may gather with other vaccinated individuals or households.   - For individuals and households who are not fully vaccinated, social gatherings indoors and outdoors in private spaces are limited to two unvaccinated households or individuals at one time, PLUS any fully vaccinated households.   - Unvaccinated households or individuals may gather with more than one other unvaccinated household or individual, as long as it is just two unvaccinated households or individuals at any one gathering.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404200509/https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-be-smart-stay-safe-order
notes_C5: As of 4 April 2021, there has been no detected change in the closure of public transport in Vermont. Continuing to code as 0.    No evidence has been found to suggest that the delivery of these services has been altered, aside from requirements for social distancing and/or wearing face coverings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404200008/https://vpta.net/
notes_C6: As of 2 April 2021, businesses are required to use remote work or telework whenever possible, including making use of teleconferencing and video conferencing to avoid in person meetings.    Individuals are also recommended to stay home if they have symptoms and to get tested for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404200509/https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-be-smart-stay-safe-order    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405105203/https://www.healthvermont.gov/sites/default/files/documents/pdf/Covid-19-Daily-Update.pdf
notes_C7: As of 4 April 2021, all travel to Vermont requires quarantine. The only exceptions are for essential travel and for people who are fully vaccinated. The Health Department and the CDC strongly recommend not traveling right now.    International travel and quarantine guidance:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404194232/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/travel-quarantine/international-travel
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: Governor Phil Scott announced in Addendum 13 to EO 01-20 that effective March 31, 2021, the emergency provisions of 21 V.S.A. § 1344(a)(2)(A), shall be extended to provide unemployment benefits to individuals who are forced to leave their employment for a COVID-19 qualifying reason.    Additionally, Bill H.742, which expands unemployment eligibility provisions for workers and offers relief to employers affected by the coronavirus pandemic, remains in effect.    H.742:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404194039/https://legislature.vermont.gov/bill/status/2020/H.742    Addendum 13 to EO 01-20:  https://archive.fo/t0awf
notes_E2: On 29 March, the Public Utility Commission issued an order extending the temporary moratorium of natural gas, electric, and traditional landline telephone service through May 31, 2021.    Additionally, S.333 remains in effect. This prohibits evictions until 30 days after the termination of the state of emergency.    Order extending the utility disconnection moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404192154/https://documentcloud.adobe.com/link/track?uri=urn%3Aaaid%3Ascds%3AUS%3A73cb866e-627b-4bd0-b0ec-ee235c821509    S.333:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404192007/https://legislature.vermont.gov/bill/status/2020/S.333
notes_H1: As of 4 April 2021, Vermont's COVID-19 website remains live.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404191652/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19
notes_H2: As of 4 April 2021, COVID-19 testing remains to be generally available across Vermont. There are a large number of testing sites across the state, these are available on an open public testing basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404191400/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/testing/where-get-tested
notes_H3: As of 27 March 2021, Vermont traced 987 cases in the past two weeks. 87% of cases were interviewed within 24 hours, continuing to justify a 2.     See the data for week of March 27:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404191106/https://www.healthvermont.gov/sites/default/files/documents/pdf/COVID19-Weekly-Data-Summary-4-2-2021.pdf
notes_H6: As of 4 April 2021, face coverings are still required in all public spaces.    Vermont Facial Covering Guidance:  https://archive.fo/VDR5y
notes_H7: As of 29 March 2021, all Vermonters aged 50 and older are eligible for vaccination. Now coding as 4G.    The following groups are now eligible for vaccination in Vermont:  - Long-term care residents and staff, health care, first responders  - Those aged 16+ with certain high-risk health conditions  - K-12 teachers and staff, child care, public safety  - Those aged 50+    According to the Vermont Department of Health website, the Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are being administered.    Press release:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404190343/https://www.healthvermont.gov/media/newsroom/governor-phil-scott-details-vaccination-timeline-for-all-age-bands-March-19-2021    Vaccine types:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404190433/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/vaccine/about-covid-19-vaccines-vermont

name: Washington
notes_C1: Every school district is still operating a version of hybrid teaching (both in-person and online) except for Kent school district.  Kent county is 100% remote and the only college in Kent, the Kent location of the Green River Community College is also only remote.   Given that the every level in Kent is remote, the coding has been changed to 3T from 2T.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195914/https://www.k12.wa.us/about-ospi/press-releases/novel-coronavirus-covid-19-guidance-resources/school-reopening-data    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408191707/https://www.greenriver.edu/campus/campus-safety/emergency-preparedness/covid19/
notes_C2: All counties remain in Phase 3 of the Roadmap to Recovery plan. Most sectors are able to operate at reduced capacity, remote work is "strongly encouraged" for professional services. For more detailed information, visit archived link.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329201727/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C3: Although restrictions on residential/private gatherings are still in place (10 indoor, 50 outdoor) in Phase 3 of Washington's Recovery Plan, Phase 3 allows up to 50% occupancy or 400 people maximum, whichever is lower, for all indoor spaces. This applies to all industries and indoor activities currently allowed; restaurants, gyms and fitness centers and movie theaters, among others.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329200916/https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-announces-statewide-move-to-phase-3-of-recovery-plan-return-to-spectator-events-and-tier-2-4a53000f2724
notes_C4: Phase 3 of Healthy Washington: Roadmap to Recovery is in place for all counties in Washington. Limit of 10 people may gather indoors. Limit of 50 may gather outside.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329201727/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C5: Sound Transit (a large regional transit system) is tracking ridership and will adjust bus and train service in order to meet demand and allow passengers to ride safely.     King County Metro is operating on reduced service, though it sites budget constraints, not Covid-19, as the reason.     Pierce Transit is offering reduced service to maintain safety and adequate cleaning.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329203341/https://kingcounty.gov/depts/transportation/metro/schedules-maps/healthier-metro.aspx    Sound transit: https://archive.vn/EHUXv    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329203302/https://www.piercetransit.org/
notes_C6: Staying at home and continuing to practice physical distancing is encouraged.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329204617/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/stay-home-stay-healthy
notes_C7: On April 6th, the governor of Washington updated his guidelines for both interstate and international travel:   "Gov. Jay Inslee today updated Proclamation 20-83 to clarify that, in addition to requiring compliance with CDC restrictions related to international flight travel, all other types of travel, including intrastate travel, should also follow CDC guidance and requirements"    and that:   ", I hereby prohibit any individual from  traveling by air from any location outside of the United States to Washington state, directly  or indirectly, unless that individual complies with the requirements established by the CDC  that can be found at this website. Individuals exempted from the CDC requirements are also  exempt from this proclamation...I issued a travel advisory on November 13, 2020, recommending that  travelers avoid non-essential travel and self-quarantine upon arriving in Washington from  out of state. I rescinded that travel advisory on March 19, 2021, and instead recommended  that travelers follow the CDC’s COVID-19 travel guidance."    See archives:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210407083340/governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-updates-travel-restriction-proclamation    https://web.archive.org/web/20210413094244/https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-83.2.pdf
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: Pandemic unemployment benefits continue.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210315195409/https://esd.wa.gov/unemployment/cares-act
notes_E2: Washington's eviction moratorium is extended through June 2021.     The Washington Utilities and Transportation Commission's October 15 order remains in effect: investor-owned electric and natural gas utilities in Washington must continue a moratorium on disconnections for nonpayment until April 30, 2021. Also, utilities will continue to waive deposits for new customers and all late fees through Oct. 27, 2021.    Eviction moratorium: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329222853/https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-announces-extension-of-eviction-moratorium-expansion-of-vaccine-eligibility-long-term-635b34eb0ca    WA UTC: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329223045/https://www.utc.wa.gov/regulated-industries/doing-business/covid-19-response
notes_H1: The state continues to share information and provides a toolkit to "spread the facts" about Covid-19. https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224017/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/partner-toolkit
notes_H2: Testing is widely available for anyone who would like to be tested.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210315160056/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/TestingforCOVID19
notes_H3: DOH centralized investigation targets for the timeliness of case investigation & contact tracing are:  • 90% of cases will be reached within 1 day of DOH receiving a positive test result  • 80% of contacts be reached within 2 days of DOH receiving a positive test result for the case    Washington's most recent data (March 7-13) shows they reached 52% of case investigations within one day (total percentage interviewed: 65%), and reached 72% of traced contacts within 2 days (for a total percentage of contacts interviewed at 82%).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329231520/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/data-tables/COVID19-CaseInvestigationContractTracingReport.pdf
notes_H6: Masks continue to be required outside of the home. For more information:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329233757/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/information-for/you-and-your-family/face-masks-or-cloth-face-covering
notes_H7: On March 31st, the governor announced:  "Gov. Jay Inslee today announced that effective April 15, all Washingtonians age 16 and up will be eligible to receive a COVID-19 vaccination."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210331225634/https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-vaccine-eligibility-expansion-all-adults-april-15    The previous vaccine policy still stands:   High-risk critical workers* in the following industries: agriculture, fishing vessel crews, food processing, grocery store/food bank, corrections (prisons, jails, detention centers), court of law, public transit, and remaining first responders  People 16 years or older who are pregnant or have a disability that puts them at high risk for severe COVID-19 illness  Anyone 65 and older  All people 50 and older who also live in a multigenerational household  All workers at risk in health care settings  Educators and school staff for pre-kindergarten through 12th grade, and child care workers  People who live or work in long-term care facilities    Moderna, Pfizer, and Janssen vaccines are all being used in Washington. Over three million people have received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine in Washington (as of 3/27/21).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329232100/https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-announces-extension-of-eviction-moratorium-expansion-of-vaccine-eligibility-long-term-635b34eb0ca    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329233532/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/DataDashboard

name: Wisconsin
notes_C1: As of the 8th of March, many schools districts have schools that are operating remote, partially remote or in-person teaching. For example, the Milwaukee Public Schools district is planning a phased reopening for in-person learning with Pre-K through grade 2 will beginning on April 12, 2021, students in grades 3 through 8 will begin April 19, 2021, and students in grades 9 through 12 will begin April 26, 2021. The Elmbrook School District offers both virtual and in-person learning options for students.     Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308105104/https://mps.milwaukee.k12.wi.us/en/District/Superintendent/Blog/Roadmap-to-Readiness-Update-January-2021.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308105626/https://www.elmbrookschools.org/community/learninghub
notes_C2: On the 8th of March, Executive Order 105 that was issued by Governor Evers remains in place. The order declares a state of public health emergency in response to the spread of the coronavirus throughout Wisconsin. This maintains that people should stay at home as much as possible.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf
notes_C3: As of 8 March, Executive order 105 is still in place declaring a public health emergency specifically related to the new B.1.1.7 variant. This order urges people to stay at home as much as possible.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf
notes_C4: As of 8 March, Executive order 105, relating to the state of the public health emergency issued by Governor Evers remain in place. It recommends  wearing a face covering whenever they are indoors with people who are not part of their household, staying at least six feet away from other people when they leave home.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf
notes_C5: The Wisconsin department of health services states that "COVID-19 case patients and close contacts are prohibited from using public transportation (for example, airplane, bus, ship, shuttle) during their isolation or quarantine periods." The City of Madison is also reducing their capacity  on all Metro Transit fixed-route buses to 20 passengers plus the driver.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201222535/https://www.cityofmadison.com/metro/contact/covid-19-updates    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224190929/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/travel.htm
notes_C6: As of 8 March, Executive order 105 is still in place declaring a public health emergency specifically related to the new B.1.1.7 variant. This order urges people to stay at home as much as possible to prevent the spread of the new variant.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf
notes_C7: As of 8 March, Executive order 105 is still in place declaring a public health emergency specifically related to the new B.1.1.7 variant. This order urges people to stay at home as much as possible to prevent the spread of the new variant.     The DHS also recommends that people should cancel or postpone internal travel.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224190929/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/travel.htm
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: As of December 1st, the Department of Workforce Development still detailed unemployment benefits, as well as several extensions to benefits due to the pandemic.     See archive:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201201011650/https://dwd.wisconsin.gov/covid19/public/ui.htm#collapse1-23
notes_E2: As of February 1, 2021, the annual winter moratorium on utilities, which lasts until April 15, 2021, is still in effect. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201029025941/https://apps.psc.wi.gov/APPS/NewsReleases/content/PDF_download.aspx?id=663
notes_H1: As of 8 March, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services is still operating a coordinated public health information campaign.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210304145019/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/index.htm
notes_H2: As of 8 March, testing is still generally available through primary care providers, community testing sites and at home specimen kits (at no cost to Wisconsinites).    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210220021543/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/testing.htm
notes_H3: As of 8 March, a comprehensive contact tracing system remains in place.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301144135/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/contact-tracing.htm
notes_H6: On March 31st, the Wisconsin Supreme Court overturned the statewide mask mandate in a 4-3 vote. In this ruling, the WI Supreme Court blocked Gov. Evers from issuing any new mask mandates without the approval of the state legislature. However, there are still mask mandates in some cities throughout the state. As such, the coding switches from 3G to 3T.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405031351/https://www.jsonline.com/story/communities/lake-country/news/2021/04/02/wisconsin-schools-still-require-masks-despite-revoked-statewide-order/4836216001/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407230612/https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/31/supreme-court-blocks-tony-evers-extending-covid-mask-mandate/7060433002/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409011026/https://www.tmj4.com/news/coronavirus/these-are-the-mask-orders-still-in-effect-in-se-wisconsin-and-when-they-expire
notes_H7: As of April 5, 2021, anyone age 16 and over will be eligible for the vaccine (Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson). The priorities will still be essential workers and clinically vulnerable individuals.   Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405221755/https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/WIGOV/bulletins/2ca3d5f  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405222516/https://www.channel3000.com/everyone-16-and-older-is-now-eligible-for-the-covid-vaccine-in-wisconsin/

name: West Virginia
notes_C1: During the briefing on March 24th, Gov. Justice clarified that the color-coded County Alert System map will no longer be used to determine high school schedules in West Virginia. “I’m really happy to say that all of our schools are open because it’s going to fill a void for our students,” Gov. Justice continued.    All high schools will join all of West Virginia’s Pre-K-8 schools in being open full-time and will remain open unless there is an active outbreak that would require a particular classroom within a school to close for safety reasons, a determination that will be made by local health and education officials.    Code changed from 1T to 1G as all schools are open, but with precautions such as masks and cleaning procedures in place – therefore significant differences are in place compared to non-Covid-19 operations.     Website here: https://archive.fo/aLspC
notes_C2: Many states are allowing businesses to reopen at specified capacity restrictions and/or closing-time restrictions. However, no states seem to be requiring specific sectors to remain completely closed.    Link to Husch-Blackwell state-by-state COVID-19 policies:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329165030/https://www.huschblackwell.com/state-by-state-covid-19-guidance  Link to AARP article on state-by-state restrictions:  https://archive.vn/dKWcn
notes_C3: During the briefing on March 24th, Gov. Justice announced that he would be allowing all types of live music performances to resume, effective at midnight.    The executive order also allows all summer camps to resume on May 1, 2021. All live music performances and summer camp operations must follow all applicable safety guidelines.    Code remains 2T as not all events have been opened up.    Website here: https://archive.fo/aLspC
notes_C4: On March 5, 2021, Governor Jim Justice announced that, with immediate effect, that capacity for restaurants and bars will increase from 75% to 100% if social distancing can be maintained between groups. As long as rules are followed around distancing and facial coverings, capacity will also be increased, for small businesses, shops, grocery stores and venues such as gyms, fitness centers, and museums, to 100% of their capacity. Gatherings are increased from 75 to 100 people, meaning the code remains at 3G. Webpage here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308211813/https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2021/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-loosens-restrictions-on-businesses,-social-gatherings,-and-youth-travel-sports.aspx
notes_C5: NO NOTES
notes_C6: No changes noted.
notes_C7: No changes noted.
notes_C8: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. The following changes have been made to international travel guidance:    "Because of the potential introduction and spread of new SARS-CoV-2 variants, differences in disease burden and vaccines, and vaccine coverage around the world, CDC is providing the following guidance related to international travel:    - Fully vaccinated people can travel internationally without getting a COVID-19 test before travel unless it is required by the international destination.  - Fully vaccinated people do not need to self-quarantine after returning to the United States, unless required by a state or local jurisdiction.  - Fully vaccinated people must still have a negative COVID-19 test result before they board a flight to the United States and get a COVID-19 test 3 to 5 days after returning from international travel.  - Fully vaccinated people should continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling internationally."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: On 21 December, Governor Justice appeared in an informational video about mask-wearing entitled 'It's not forever, it's for each other'. The video is linked to the state's COVID-19 timeline: http://web.archive.org/web/20210104235523/https://governor.wv.gov/Pages/WV-COVID-19-actions-and-executive-orders.aspx
notes_H2: 8 February update: West Virginia's Department of Health & Human Resources has 'FREE COVID-19 TESTING' as a key webpage on its COVID-19 website. It states that testing is available 'for all West Virginians' free of charge. Symptoms are not mentioned at all, and the list of testing centres is robust.     See the webpage here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208203417/https://dhhr.wv.gov/COVID-19/Pages/testing.aspx
notes_H3: On November 13,Gov. Justice issued an executive order, requiring that all doctors, nurses, staff, and employees working at nursing homes and assisted living facilities throughout the state be tested for COVID-19 twice a week.    See the governor press release, archived:https://web.archive.org/web/20201117020756/https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2020/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-broadens-statewide-indoor-face-covering-requirement;-announces-adjustments-to-school-calendar.aspx
notes_H6: The state's face covering mandate is still in effect, and Governor Jim Justice continues to remind West Virginians of this fact at his regular briefings. See the 25 January briefing, for example: http://web.archive.org/web/20210201210301/https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2021/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-announces-new-online-vaccination-scheduling-system;-clinics-to-be-available-in-all-55-counties.aspx
notes_H7: During the briefing on Monday April 5th, Gov. Justice called upon younger West Virginians, urging them to sign up to be vaccinated as soon as possible, with COVID-19 numbers slowly creeping back up across certain areas of the state. “Our medical experts are confirming that the COVID variants that are out there now are really starting to attack our younger folks, so we need to watch,” Gov. Justice continued.    Web page here: https://archive.fo/ipZXa

name: Wyoming

notes_C7: On April 2, the CDC issued new travel guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals which differ from those for unvaccinated people. According to these new guidelines,     "The CDC recommends that fully vaccinated people can travel at low risk to themselves. A person is considered fully vaccinated two weeks after receiving the last recommended dose of vaccine.    Fully vaccinated people can travel within the United States and do not need COVID-19 testing or post-travel self-quarantine as long as they continue to take COVID-19 precautions while traveling – wearing a mask, avoiding crowds, socially distancing, and washing hands frequently."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p0402-travel-guidance-vaccinated-people.html
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7." notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: There is a comprehensive public health campaign.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409202104/https:/health.wyo.gov/publichealth/infectious-disease-epidemiology-unit/disease/novel-coronavirus/covid-19-orders-and-guidance/
notes_H2: Testing remains widely available for residents.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409202429/https://health.wyo.gov/publichealth/infectious-disease-epidemiology-unit/disease/novel-coronavirus/covid-19-at-home-testing/
notes_H3: State of Wyoming has stopped calling contacts of positive Covid tests.  Some counties and tribes continue on.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301134936/https://undark.org/2021/01/05/wyoming-state-stops-contact-tracing/
notes_H6: There is no statewide mask mandate and governor has rejected re-imposing one.  Masks are still required in schools.  However, some counties such as Teton county have retained a mask requirement when indoors in public or in line.  Requirement continues at least through April 16.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205175332/https://apnews.com/hub/mark-gordon  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409202104/https://health.wyo.gov/publichealth/infectious-disease-epidemiology-unit/disease/novel-coronavirus/covid-19-orders-and-guidance/  Teton County order: https://archive.fo/hE8Ip  This archived link cuts off the full text of the google doc so this is the link to the original doc.  Wayback would not archive it.  https://www.tetoncountywy.gov/DocumentCenter/View/17725/TetonFaceCovering213_20210312_Signed
notes_H7: Wyoming is vaccinating the general public with Pfizer, Modern and Jansen.  ABC  https://web.archive.org/web/20210410192905/https://health.wyo.gov/publichealth/immunization/wyoming-covid-19-vaccine-information/
